description:
I'm pretty sure I saw the owner *smiling* while bussing tables...And when I started eating I made the mistake of thinking it wasn't going to be enough food--thankfully stuffed all that injera in my face but I had to leave some beautiful bites behind.

 Eat here! Such love!
author: Hungry W.

description:
Tasty Ethiopian spot! We ordered the Veggie Sampler which was flavorful and enough for two people. Also, the food came out after only 15 minutes of waiting. The second plate of food we ordered was somewhat lukewarm, which was probably just because we went an hour before closing.

Highly recommend if you're ever in the area!
author: Aliyah B.

description:
Excellent food, nice decor, friendly, efficient service, diverse clientele. Where I live, Ethiopian food is non-existent, so I jumped at the chance to eat Moya's cooking when I found out they were right next door to our motel.

I ordered the veggie combo with injera (to go). It was hotter than Hades in the restaurant. Other than that and the fact that the cabbage was a bit undercooked, everything was great. Nice selection of beverages, included ginger beer.
author: J R.

description: Meh. I got the doro tibs and it wasn't anything special. I was expecting some sauce with the chicken but it was pretty bare. Not spicy at all even though I asked for spicy. I need to find a better Ethiopian place.
author: Lulu K.

description: Delicious as always. Boyfriend and I split the veggie sampler, which was the perfect amount of food given neither of us was very hungry. When we are hungrier, we'll order a shuro or the beef tibs.
author: Julia C.

description:
I am so happy that I found this gem of a restaurant! Casual vibe, delicious food and friendly service! 

Why I was here // I was craving Ethiopian food and we found this place! I feel like there aren't too many Ethiopian places in the city, so I was super excited to come and eat at this place! 

Service // You order at the counter and then grab a seat, where they will bring the food to you. They were all super friendly and welcoming! 

Food // Love the injera (teff flour flat bread) - I don't know what magic they do to make it, but it's amazing! I you want to buy a side of injera, its about $2.00! 

- We got the vegetarian sampler platter, which was a great choice because it comes with good variety. 
- We also ordered the chicken tibs, which had great flavor! 

Overall // Will definitely be coming back! Love the food and the injera is so addicting!
author: Emily T.

description:
I love payday - who doesn't?! It means I get to indulge on a nice, table for one lunch. There was a new yipster "all-day" restaurant that I wanted to check out but they only open for lunch on the weekends. 

Umm ok, so plan b? 

My Yelp bookmarks. 

I've had Moya bookmarked for years (before they had relocated due to a fire) so it was time to finally knock this bad boy off my list.

Sadly, Yelp led me astray on this one and I'm really surprised by all the 5 star reviews for Moya. The food is mediocre at best and the service is cold. It isn't exactly cheap either ($20 lunch w/ no beverage) so it's hard to overlook both missteps. Maybe it's raters' bias because there's so few Ethiopian restaurants in SF?

Moya is a cafe with counter service only and you order at the register from the chalkboard menu which has no listed prices. What's up with NOT listing prices?! But, since I paid with a credit card, Square emailed me an itemized receipt. 

I ordered the Doro Wot ($13.50), an Ethiopian Chicken stew that's the national dish of Ethiopia. It comes with yellow lentils, a side salad, chopped tomatoes, and brown rice or injera. Opted for the brown rice with a side of injera (+$2): http://bit.ly/2xqwewt. I received injera instead of the brown rice so I had a huge portion of injera. Not a big problem. 

While Ethiopian cuisine doesn't have a strong presence in San Francisco, I've tried a handful of Ethiopian places and the food here is weak in comparison. The chicken drumsticks were dry and the spices seemed to be toned down for the American palate. Per their menu, it's suppose to be "SPICY!" but it wasn't. It was a scotch over mild. Usually, I'm sweating and my snot runs from the robust Ethiopian spices. Not here.

The accompanying lentils were undercooked, hard, and flavorless, while the salad dressing was too sour.

The injera, the spongy, sour flatbread was fine. It had the proper texture and just the right amount of sourness. 

I can see why so many people complain about the service at Moya. Granted, it's not some fancy, Michelin starred place but there's a certain amount of courtesy paying customers should receive. 

The staff is not friendly and seem like they don't want to be there. I had called earlier in the day to check if they were serving a particular item that day and the lady I spoke with seemed annoyed that I even called. 

Then, while I was waiting for my order, two customers were waiting in line to order and the person cooking who is also the cashier passed by them several times with no sense of urgency and ignoring their presence. Pretty rude IMO...a simple, "I'll be right with you" would have been the proper thing to do.

It's counter service so these things can be overlooked but NOT when customers can only denote a 20%, 25%, or 30% tip when paying with a card (didn't see an option for "custom tip") . I always tip but I didn't appreciate being forced to tip a minimum of 20% for a counter service especially since they weren't nice. IMO, more appropriate tip options for counter service is 10%, 15%, and 18%. 

Can't say I would recommend Moya to anyone, even for convenience. For legit Ethiopian food that will make your snot run, served by an earnest owner, go to Massawa in North Beach: https://www.yelp.com/biz/massawa-restaurant-san-francisco-2.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I really like this place.  The food is delicious and the staff are very nice.  I love the salad served on the side of dishes, so fresh and with a bit of a jalapeño kick.  Keep up the good work Moya! Amesegenalo!
author: Ari A.

description: Loved this place! Dori wot and Veggie platter were delicious. Definitely coming back.
author: Navneet S.

description:
Want a simple, quick, home-cooked, authentic Ethiopian meal? Then Moya is your place. We decided to go here after having some beers two blocks away at Cellarmaker and this fit the bill. 

I won't lie, I was skeptical when I walked in because I've been to a few Ethiopian restaurants and they usually try to make it a more classy, restaurant feel but this one felt like counter service cooked by a family. Sure, the lady behind the counter isn't the most welcoming but she cooks a mean meal. We ordered a siga tibs (beef) and misir wot (spicy lentils) and it was served in a nice big plate with plenty of injera to share and a fresh green salad in the center. Everything was flavorful and delicious. The food arrived quickly and tasted so good! There's water on the side but they have a few drinks you can buy too. 
Overall, this meal was just under $30 and made us both full and happy. 

Gluten intolerant folks rejoice! This is real injera bread that is totally gluten-free. Not to mention, delicious and served generously. 

Next time I swing by SoMa and eat at Cellarmaker, I'll definitely come back for more.
author: Kim L.

description:
The menu here is a bit more compact than many other Ethiopian places in the Bay Area, but maybe there's something to be said about keeping things simple. 

The doro tibs (chicken breast marinated in white wine sauce and stir fried with onion, tomato, garlic, and berbere) were super tasty and well-portioned given the $11.50 price. They came with a good heap of decent injera. If it all wasn't savory enough, a side of ayb (Ethiopian cheese made from buttermilk) made it all quite a filling meal shareable between two. 

The venue is compact but reasonably clean and bright, and grabbing a to-go order here was a breeze. The folks behind the counter were super sweet. Worth a shot if you're already in the area.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Been here 3 times and I've been very happy each time I've ate here.

Veggie Sampler-
           spicy red lentil: probably the dish doing the least for me out of the veggie options 
           gomen: you can't really screw up collard greens
           atkilt wot: this is the borderline addicting veggie item
Doro Tibs- This is personally my favorite dish to order! I normally get this and one of the veggie items, depending on whose with me and what they're in the mood for.
Kitfo- So the kitfo is good but man, I can't handle that much raw beef personally so I steer clear of this but my friends are a huge fan.

Overall I just absolutely LOVE injera and can eat it all day. Moya isn't my go-to Ethiopian place in the city but it's definitely very convenient because it's fast casual as opposed to a formal sit down like most of the other spaces in the city.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Very interesting restaurant. Honest food. Cooking very tasty and special pancakes are fermented very good. Beans have a good texture and smell as nut.
Go ahead!
author: Marie-Claire L.

description: I would say just totally fine Ethiopian, nothing too special.  They don't ruin anything but don't master anything either. Everything tasted ok with no standouts.  Wouldn't return but wouldn't say don't try it if you're craving Ethiopian.
author: Saminda W.

description:
This place is no Tadu, but I'd been wanting to try it for awhile. It's more of a café where you can get work done, but I stopped by for a quick me-time dinner before socializing with friends on a Friday night. The process for ordering is straightforward. There's a simple menu posted above the counter, and you order at the cashier before getting your number and finding a seat.

I decided on the kitfo, which is essentially raw meat with the standard injera and house salad to complement the flavor. The plate is a decent amount of food. Actually, it was much more than I could finish, but it was pretty good! After awhile, I couldn't stomach any more raw meat, so I gave up and called it a day. Initially I wanted tibs, but they only had chicken.

It's a dimly lit café and has a very low-key vibe. I saw people come here on a chill date and to catch up with friends. Very versatile location. It doesn't compel me enough to come here again, but there's decent food and doubles as a café, which is awesome!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I came back to Moya for the first time in a very long time (I no longer work around the corner). The food is still amazing as it has ever been! I cannot recommend enough the Kitfo Special!

On top of everything, the owners still remember me and spoke with me even though it's easily been two years since I came by.

Thank you for still providing amazing food! I hope to be back sooner than later!
author: Robby F.

description:
I was brought to this place by my friend who's an Ethiopian food expert. He was a journalist who served as a war correspondent there and married an Ethiopian woman. So yeah, he's an expert.

This is an order-at-the-counter restaurant that serves relative few dishes and they make them very well. I have the steak tips and the flavors were on point. Succulent steak and a salad with bright green dressing and tomato. I added collard greens and they were delicious. All the better to eat up with the Injera bread. He had the Kitfo, an Ethiopian steak tartare. Too bad they don't serve alcohol here. But a ginger beer washes things down just fine. 

I didn't really count but they're probably eight or nine tables, 4- and 2-tops. While the restaurant is clean, the atmosphere is good, not great. A basic look dressed up with some Ethiopian art. Never got crowded but it stayed busy until almost closing time when I was there on a Wednesday night. The woman at the counter was extremely friendly. Nothing to complain about and the price was right at just $14. 

Don't get faked out by the out-of-order sign on the bathroom door. I'm pretty sure that's to discourage the vagrants. Just ask for the bathroom key and everything is clean and in working order.
author: Ted R.

description: Great food and staff. Also healthy. Love the vegetables sampler. It's nice to have a local place.
author: Wayne S.

description: I looooove Ethiopian food and was glad to find this place. Friendly service and a delicious, soft, perfectly sour injera. However, the food can be inconsistent. One time the veggie platter was great, and the next time it was wayyyy over salted (everything was salty).
author: J. A.

description: My first time having Ethiopian food. I got for tibs and injera bread. The portion was large and the bread soaked up the sauce well. It was a delicious meal and bread is so soft and spongey. Would come back to try their other dishes.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Ok so I not a fan of Ethiopian food at all so I am probably not the best person to be writing this review. We came here for a coworkers birthday dinner and he happens to love Ethiopian food which is all that matters right? The food was a bit spicer than I would have liked and the sourdough bread that was soft was just weird! It looked the skin to me and the whole time I was grossed out by it. Again because I was not a fan of this food I didn't like the place but for people who are fans it is probably not a bad place! The place itself is on the smaller side and you order at the county. Not in the nicest or cleanest place in the city but then again hey which place is in the city?
author: Anne R.

description: It's definitely a benefit to come here in a group and eat family style on a big platter because you get to try almost everything on the menu. I definitely recommend the vegetable sampler, siga (beef) tibs, doro wat (chicken chili stew), and shuro (ground chickpea stew). I've yet to try the kitfo but you can bet I'll be back for it!
author: Mark C.

description:
Favorite Place to get. Good meal in SF 

Toro Dibs is my favorite ! 
Chicken stir fried with tomatoes and onions, juicy, with beans and the traditional bread ! 

Bomb !
author: Jimmy M.

description:
moya is pretty tasty. Red lentils were my fave. 
service was adequate, and no drinks but water and soda. 
i liked the food but the place and service was underwhelming.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Food = delicious, fresh and worth the wait.

Doro wot = chicken drumsticks in a spicy chili stew, comes with a green salad and choice of brown rice or injera. Delicious and plenty for one person. $13.50

Service = friendly. A bit slow, but totally worth the wait!

Seating = 4-tops and 2-tops. Rearranging needed for larger groups.

Prices = moderate. Worth it.
author: Fannie S.

description: Came in randomly and we were pleasantly impressed. The staff was friendly and it was easy to order. For the food itself, I had the doro tibs with brown rice, while my brother had the siga tibs with bread and mushrooms. I tried both of them and I couldn't decide which was better! The service is fast and the food is good. Will come back again!
author: Michael Z.

description: we got the vegetarian platter and chicken tibs to share between two people and it was more than enough food! the tibs were particularly good and the rest of the food had a homey and authentic flavor as well. Great value for money.
author: Rachel N.

description:
I went there for lunch with some friends. The food was delicious but . . . I paid $1 extra for mushrooms to go with my siga tibs and the cook barely gave me any mushrooms. I think there were three small slices of mushroom (less than one whole mushroom) on the whole plate. On the whole, the restaurant seems to be stingy with sides despite being, in my opinion, a little overpriced. We had to pay $2 more for some more injera bread even though what we got with our orders wasn't much. The size of the main dish/entree was average, what you'd expect (basically, enough for one meal). 

The service is okay. I find it a little annoying that they suggest a 20% and above tip, though you can change this to what you think is reasonable.  

On the whole, I'd give Moya 3.5 stars, but am erring on the side of generous since the food (minus the bland, yellow lentils) was tasty.
author: Anne O.

description: SOo, This is my first time trying Ethiopian food and this is my first time eating at MOYA, soooo delicious! - I got the Veggie Platter, Oh oh, Sooo good. I will be back! ohh yess !!
author: Veronica M.

description: Delicious food and fast service. If you've never had Ethiopian food, you should stay here. Simple menu with tasty selections.
author: Michael G.

description: Food is really yummy, service could be better, space is small but good and the walls have great graffiti.
author: Paola L.

description: My fav Ethiopian in the city. Much more flavorful and friendly than Axum. The location is kinda nice cos it's at 9th/Howard in soma, so it's close to civic center muni and downtown. Parking sucks in soma, take a bus or lyft. Injera was perfect and my vegetarian plate was so satisfying and yummy. I definitely try to get here when I'm in town, and when friends from SF visit me in hawaii, they have to bring Moya food in ziplocks to me. And actually, they know my mom now and tell her just to bring Tupperwares and they put everything in containers so she can bring it to me when she visits. They also gave us a tip- that you can freeze Ethiopian food (not the injeera duh) overnight then put it in your checked luggage. By the time it gets to hawaii it's barely defrosted. So if you're reading this and coming to Maui, hmu:)
author: Aliantha L.

description:
One of my favourite little spots in the city. I came across Moya in 2015 and been a regular since. The food is authentic Ethiopian and always reminds me of the meals I enjoyed in Addis Ababa. Great joint for vegetarian dishes and the service is nice and warm.

The sitting area is limited, but I've never missed a seat, so can't complain! :)
author: Martha C.

description: The food is just as good as it smells! My friend recommended the Kitfo and he was right to do so!
author: Tyler H.

description:
Moya is a coffee stop that offers Ethiopian vegeterian and meat dishfes, no sammies.

eats: Misir Wot) spicy red lentils stew, 10.95)
-choose injera bread, great for dipping
-small, tasty. fresh spring mix salad
-misor wot had some heat, filled me up quickly
hungry an hour later, too busy to grab something else to eat.
3 stars quantity, 4 stars quality.

take outs:
-found park, but ate on the run. (spot lights)
-food $4 higher than food truck for equivalent eats.
.s.f. rates not cheap either.
-quick service, smiple menu. next time trying another veggie stew. no meats yet.
-parking found in alley....no meters.
author: Victor G.

description:
Very tasty vegetable sampler. Satisfied my craving for Ethiopian cuisine.

The only problem is they don't offer any samplers for the meat dishes. I wish they offered an option to add on a small portion of meat dish to the veggie sampler for $2-$4. Would be well worth it. I asked but they wouldn't allow it.
author: Ben D.

description:
We were super excited to find an Ethiopian restaurant only a couple blocks away from our apartment so we had to give it a try. You order at the counter and then take a seat. The walls are covered with beautiful murals and some look to tell the life story of the owner which I thought was really cool! The food was great, plenty of injera and great portions. The service was friendly and the food was served up super quickly. To move this review to a 5 star here is what the restaurant would need to improve upon: play some cool Ethiopian music (no music was on while we were there), make sure the bathroom is not out of order, and perhaps add the carrot-green bean dish (unfortunately I don't know the name - and I'm just bias because this is my favorite Ethiopian dish - but all the other Ethiopian restaurants have it and I LOVE it so much! Ok end of my little rant..) 

Keep up the good work, Moya!
author: Madeline F.

description: So SOOO GOOD!!! I got the veggie platter and the steak tibs. The steak is great but the veggies shine! I had an audible reaction to every bite. Not to mention the injera was perfect...sour and spongy. This is the best flavored Ethiopian food I've ever had (I've eaten Ethiopian in Chicago, Southern California and new to SF). Moya has a new customer for life. Love it!
author: Lindsey P.

description: It was good - although I wouldn't get it delivered by door dash again.  It was really cold by the time I got it.  I got the veggie platter and injera.  Next time I would just get the spicy red lentils and yellow pea stew, and not the whole platter.  Everything else was just okay.  I am not a fan of collard greens though, so I won't ever be impressed by those.
author: Amanda B.

description: First time having Ethiopian food and I liked it.  I had no idea what to expect so I tried the chicken drumsticks and my friend got the beef. Both of our entrees were served on a huge colorful platter and my meal came with  a hard boiled egg too.  The dressing on the salad was good and it was served with these pillowlike rolls that had a slightly sour flavor.  Kind of like sourdough and you can unroll the bread for a tortilla experience.  A little pricey for the small portion you get and expect a bit of a wait because they make it fresh.
author: Lindsay C.

description: The food is amazing!!!!!!!! I would highly recommend this place to everyone. The staff is incredibly nice.
author: Tee S.

description: The food was a six out of ten. Good food. The colorful design was great.The customer service was a big ZERO!
author: Vickiy G.

description:
Had dinner with a friend over here. The cafe was decent although really warm inside. The lady(owner?) said we could open a window, so wasn't a big deal. 
You have to order at the counter. The food took about 20 minutes to arrive. The injera was the best I ever had. Very tangy and also very light. I was surprised at the small portion size and expected more on my plate (we ordered 2 vegan entrees for sharing - mushroom and chickpeas). The chickpea entree was really good but the mushroom was bland. 3.5 stars overall. 

Not a big fan of the location though, as I was walking up here the lady in front of me was robbed of her water bottle. I ended up running the last hundred feet to the restaurant. Obviously not the restaurants fault and did not affect my rating score, just wanted to point it out for safety reasons.
author: Meghna G.

description:
Horrible service.

I ordered through Yelp (eat24) for take out at 1130. Pickup scheduled for 1210. Small order (1 meal)

I got there at 1215. Waited in line to find out they haven't even started my order.

The entire time I am waiting I see the cook standing around between orders. They only start my meal once I asked about my order after waiting in line.

I don't understand what the point of ordering online and choosing a pick up time is good for. They don't even check it.

The chicken tibs was way too sour and I couldn't even finish it.

I asked eat24 for a refund, they asked if I accepted the order.. obviously after waiting that long and on a limited lunch time I can't just go somewhere else at that point.

Never going back. I don't recommend using eat24 either.
author: Gabriel S.

description: One word "WOW" this is the best Ethiopian food hands down In the Bay Area everything was on point top notch customer service, the resturant is super clean and I truly love the music that they play at the resturant so relaxing, you can taste the freshness of the meats and sauces I will defiantly come back, keep up the good work
author: Tycoon N.

description: At first, the only reason why I wanted to check this spot out was because the name of this restaurant happens to be my last name! Now, I've had Ethiopian food but nothing like this one. It's a pretty small location but the food is great. Servings are pretty big and the lady always has a huge smile on her face. They serve both meat and vegan! I normally order the doro tibs(chicken) with the injera! Do not forget the injera! I repeat eating your portion with injera makes it 100x better!
author: Jessica M.

description:
I ordered delivery. Yelp/Eat24 staff informed me that I might have to cancel the order because the restaurant could not be reached. After a 15 minute delay they did contact the restaurant and confirmed the order.

When it was 20 minutes past the ETA and the delivery did not show up, I had to contact support again. After another great delay I found out that they had delivered it to the wrong address. And they closed soon after so they could not re-send the order.

I was left hungry and waiting.
author: Gaurav V.

description:
Moya is a great spot for a large group. There's nothing better than good food with good company in a setting where everyone can share, not feel cramped, and eat to your heart's content. This is exactly what we did.

The space looks quite new. It's very clean with large open windows. The cleanest place on the block, you can't miss it!

The food itself is ok, a good go to if it's on your way. I found the injera to not be sour or fluffy enough. The veggies all had similar flavors, salad lacked the tangy kick that compliments the spice, and the beef was ok.

Service was great. The lady behind the counter kept refilling our injera for us and was very nice. 

There's a ton of vegan and vegetarian options!
author: Shereen A.

description: This place is delicious! I ordered for lunch on a whim and it did not disappoint. The Doro Tibs (chicken) was flavorful, with a small kick to the tastebuds. The injera was perfect, light and spongy. My coworker loved the Siga Tibs (beef). I would definitely recommend and order again!
author: Nicole P.

description: Came here on a rainy day looking for a small dinner. Surprisingly the portions here are huge!!! I looked around and noticed many people getting the veggie sample which looked delicious but will have to come back and try that next time. The lady who worked there was extremely nice and recommended I get the goursha if I wasn't very hungry. Ended up being GREAT! Asked for spicy and it was just right. Also with a little sweetness from the lentils. Can't wait to try the tibs and veggie platter
author: Tatiana T.

description:
If I could eat Moya's vegetarian combination every day the rest of my days I would be in complete bliss - literally.

I try many Ethiopian restaurants in the Bay Area and I cherish Moya in particular for many reasons: The food has real soul, something you don't find easily. All ingredients are fresh and tasty and the spices are perfectly balanced. The restaurant is welcoming and nicely framed with the Coptic-Ethiopian artwork of a young local artist.

Moya's  staff is most hospitable, efficient and kind-every time I come in they make me feel like family
author: Raúl F.

description: Great small find. Quality food! Even walking by it smells amazing. So glad I stopped in!
author: Ty R.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been to many Ethiopian restaurants. This one was very good! We ordered steak tidbits and the veggie platter. 

Although we've had better steak tidbits, the portions were huge, and they have MUSHROOMS you can add, which we've never seen before! 

The veggie plate pea lentil spread is amazing! That is really the only spread I liked out of the veggie platter.

Oh! Before I forget, please note that they do not have lamb! So be prepared for that :)
author: Nadia H.

description:
I'm PROUDLY NOT A VEGETARIAN and absolutely RELISHED every wonderful bite of Moya's steak tartare made with clarified butter!  The steak tibs and deliciously spiced chicken are just a few of the amazing offerings at Moya. Their spices come directly from Ethiopia so everything is truly, authentically amazing!

I ordered through Grub Hub and was delighted at how quickly they delivered in the POURING RAIN!  Grateful to have found such a glittering gem of a restaurant amongst the banal offerings I've experienced of late in the Mission.  Moya is DEFINITELY my go-to for future cravings of authentic Ethiopian food.  Great food, fair price and a sweet family working hard to run their business.  Enjoy!
author: Alacrity I.

description:
I've never had ethiopian food before so this was an interesting experience. I ordered the doro tibs which was the marinated chicken breast. The food tasted really good! I'm not sure what some of the stuff even was but I enjoyed it quite well. I ordered mine mild but it was not that spicy, so I might try it spicier next time. They have a lot of vegetarian/vegan options too! 

The lady taking our order seemed really bored, as if she didn't want to be there (or us to be there) so that made my experience not so great. It didn't help that I didn't know what to order since it was my first time there and she was not very helpful either. It's also a bit pricey, but I guess that's SF.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I love, love, love Ethiopian food. I was really excited to find this place just a couple of blocks from my new apartment. We ordered the vegetarian sampler, doro tibs (chicken), and siga tibs (beef). The food arrived promptly, and it was delicious. The staff was friendly and helpful. I will be eating here a lot.
author: Bradley H.

description: Moya is hands down my favorite ethiopian restaurant - I only wish I worked closer to it! Their vegan plate is delicious - the flavors are fresh and the injera is nice and spongey (not thin). I would highly recommend it if you've never tried ethiopian before or you're looking for a new spot. Get the veggie combo!
author: Lexi C.

description: This was the first time me or my mom had tried Ethiopian food and it was SO GOOD. I got the  veggie sampler and literally everything on the plate had my drooling. I didn't even realize how much I liked collard greens until I ate here. Everything was seasoned perfectly, so glad we stopped by! My mom also really enjoyed her chicken plate. Definitely recommend for veg folks and meat eaters alike!
author: Melanie L.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian food spot in San Francisco! Friendly staff and affordable prices make this cozy cafe feel warm and inviting for all. I love to bring people who have never eaten Ethiopian food here. Moya has a laid-back and casual atmosphere and is great for a quick solo lunch or a small group meal.
author: D Andrew P.

description: This place was so delicious stopped by for a quick to go lunch and ordered the veggie sampler. Sooo much flavor the service was on point. No complaints from me.
author: Bryan P.

description:
Very delicious, warm food. And super fresh 
I highly recommended this restaurant 
The beef cooked well and the spinach aside was super fresh! 
The seasonings were as good as the beef and the beef cooked well done and very tasty 
100% that I will go back again and the painting on the wall are super artistic 
Try .. Try .. Try :)
author: Mustafa A.

description: The food is great. You may have to wait a little longer than usual but that's bout it. The takeout portion feels like a rip off. Very small containers so if you come hungry you're better off dining in! Amazing artwork on the walls.
author: Macie B.

description:
I was really excited to try Ethiopian food for the first time! I got mine via Caviar and ordered the  doro wot with traditional injera. Doro wot was spicy and when I was reading the description, apparently it take hours for this dish to be prepared. I opened up the injera and ate it with the doro wot and it tasted amazing!

Every bite was flavorful and it wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be but it had that zing.

I definitely would love to sit down here and eat some time in the future!
author: Aj C.

description:
One word: Bland
Bland bland bland bland bland
I'm used to Ethiopian food that bursts with flavors that leave my palate happy, my stomach probably with a hole, and my toilet -- actually let's not go there.

I figured we could not go wrong with the veggie sampler but that was utterly disappointing. It felt like we were eating flavorless pasty mush. The medium spicy chicken with mushrooms (not sure what the actual name is) was not "medium spicy." It was more like mild and that item was nothing to rave about. The injera was also a disappointment. It was not really sour so I guess the taste could be compared to faintly sour wheat bread. This place seriously holds back on the spices to cater to Americanized stomachs. WHYYYYYY!

Other cons:
- They charge for injera
- Staff is slow at clearing tables for incoming customers to sit
- What's up with the bathroom...
author: Liana F.

description: I've walked past this restaurant over the last few months, I decided to try it out and it was very good.  The price of lunch is about $11 per plate of food.  The location is right on the edge of the tenderloin so you will see lots of people shooting up and passed out, not a place to bring kids.
author: P A.

description: A SOMA gem.  Ethiopian food is delicious at moya. Prepared for sharing, with offered options on turning up or down your preferred levels of spice.  The crepes are soft and the ingredients are magically put together.  And yes, if your vegan or vegetarian, this can be a haven for palettes with delectable tastes.
author: Shu K.

description: Moya is the best ethiopian i've ever had. Not a great dinner atmosphere but for lunch it's fast and tasty. The employees are very nice and all seems very authentic.
author: Susie D.

description: This is authentic Ethiopian food at it's best. I opt for the vegetarian dishes. If you are a foodie and like African, Indian or Middle Eastern cuisines, give this place a try...you won't be disappointed.
author: SF N.

description: Quality food with a laid back atmosphere. The owner/staff was really friendly and everyone enjoyed their dishes. Their chicken entree (the meat tibs photo in this page's album) seemed to be the the all around favorite.
author: Thomas C.

description:
This is my first time to try Ethiopian food. The place is tidy and cozy.  Food was yummy. 

The traidtional Ethiopian  injera is awesome. I love its texture and it's pretty light.  We ordered a customized veggie samplers (red lentil stew, yellow pea stew, sauteed collard greens, green salad, Shuro). Everything was tasty! Their veggie dishes are the heaven for vegan. Shuro is my favourite.
author: Shell J.

description: Ethiopian food should deserve some love.  I like how the chefs have plated perfectly, and I also like the spices.  I like to scoop the sauté mushrooms with its traditional flat bread.  It's one of the unique ways of eating Ethiopian food.  I'll be glad to go back there whenever I'm in the mood.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
The food here is amazing, and you always have enough for leftovers!
Ordering ahead through yelp is the way to go for lunch in a hurry.
author: Amber R.

description:
Gave 2 stars only because some of the food was 3 stars. Go to Berkeley - way better quality and value.

- Food: overpriced and most of it was 2 stars. Very limited menue. Small portions. Canned mushrooms for $11 and not even tasty! We were starving around the corner, the reviews were good so we went. Left still hungry.
- Overpriced: 3 dishes were $40. You pay upfront so if you didn't like it - there are no returns.
- Greedy: tip options were 20%, 25% and 30% while you order standing at the counter. 
- Service 1 star: the counter girl was spraying empty tables with windex or other chemical. It all went to our food,  faces, mouths. Basically we were eating windex.   And this is all while we had to clean our table as we arrived because it was dirty. 
I guess more people on the city means lower standards....
author: Viktoriya Z.

description: The Food was overall really great, lots of vegetarian options, we got the assorted platter and the flavors were well-blended together. Only thing is that the place didnt have enough cups/forks spoons which sucked for our large party. Also, the bathroom is broken so you cant wash your hands after/before eating...
author: Samantha B.

description: So flavorful! I just had the mushroom tibs, spicy for lunch. It was sooooooo good! I forget that I have this gem in my neighborhood, I should order more often! Thank you Moya.
author: M G.

description: Great Ethiopian food found here! Their hours are a bit annoying and when you can find them open, Moya is often packed, but its worth it in my opinion! Their beef tibs with rice is great and I love to settle in here and just enjoy my coffee long after my meal is done.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Nice gem in a sketchier part of town. Everything on the menu was delicious. I especially liked the vegetable sampler and the chicken drumsticks. They were very generous with the injera sourdough flatbreads, which were served in cute little rolls for the table to share.

The ordering process was quick and easy -- order at the counter and they bring the food to the table. The dishes were affordable at $10-13. Great for mid-size groups so you don't have to bother with splitting the bill later. Most of the tables are for 2-4, but they don't mind you combining tables together. Service was quick, and we were able to be in and out in less than an hour.

The decor was clean, modern, and fresh. The restrooms (for customers only) were actually clean!! I was pleasantly surprised. Large windows that allow lots of fresh air and light. It can get chilly at times, but feel free to close the windows.

You'd think this would be more of a lunch place, but it was decently crowded for dinner on a Saturday night around 7pm. I'd say the place was at about 75% capacity. This is great for a quick dinner since many of the other restuarants in the area probably have long waits or are fully reserved.

All-in-all, a fan of this restaurant for a clean, delicious, no-fuss bite to eat.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch but there was nothing quick about it. We ordered a couple plates and waited. The 2 people whom came after us still got their food before us, we ended up waiting a good 20 minutes before the food arrived. 

When arrived it, the waitress didn't know what it was. All they knew was what protein they had on the plate. The food itself was like eating Indian, without the curry..
author: M C.

description: Food was amazing!!! First time having Ethiopian and it was amazing.  Food is served family style. So everyone shared what you ordered.
author: Leila H.

description: Tiny place with nice staff and excellent food! Got the gluten free injera which is a deal-breaker for me. More expensive than some Ethiopian restaurants but the veggie sampler was plenty of food for two of us, so it came out less than $17 total. Right around the corner from ACT which is why we tried it. I'd definitely go back!
author: Shanna L.

description:
The some of best Ethiopian in San Francisco, however that doesn't mean much since San Francisco lacks Ethiopian restaurants. They have a decent veggie platter and offer gluten free injera, when it is available. 

The delivery through Eat24 is inconsistent (sometimes my salad is wilted and uneatable) and it is definitely not as good as ordering from there. I wish they offered Azifa (cold Ethiopian green lentil salad).

Gluten free notes: No issues for me here in terms cross contamination or errors. Since they only offer gluten free injera when it is available, this means you need to call ahead if you have to have GF.
author: Shannon Z.

description: I'm vegetarian and trying to eat healthy even if it's more difficult when you're traveling and you're on a budget. But for $10 I had this awesome meal on brown rice, with a side salad and spicy lentils. The girls were also very nice and the place has a cozy atmosphere. Glad I checked it out.
author: Francesca S.

description: This place is small and you have to wait to get your food but the food is amazing.  There was one lady there who ran the restaurant.  She took our order and then started making the food. We could see her cooking the food in a pan on the stove.  We had to wait some time for our food because there were 2 or 3 orders before us, but when we got our food, it was excellent.  Some of the best Ethiopian food I have ever eaten.  The restaurant is small probably could only fit 5 or 6 families of 4 in the whole restaurant.  We ordered the lentils, chicken, and ground beef.  Everything was excellent.
author: Abbas B.

description:
Moya is back after its incendiary experience on Folsom over a year ago when it suffered the unlucky fate of an out-of-control, four-alarm fire. Jamie W. and I were lucky enough to try the place in its early days, and we really enjoyed the fresh ingredients and cordial service of this Ethiopian eatery (see review below), so we were sad that chef and owner Fana Alemayehu and her three daughters had to close their business and move. Luckily, one year later, they have been able to start over again in a location not that far away - 9th Street near Mission - where they are more likely to get more foot traffic and hopefully Twitter lunch-hour overflow.

I came by alone after work last week. The new space feels a bit smaller and more generic, but they've warmed it up with their native artwork. The takeout menu with the tiny font lists the same appetizing dishes I remembered from their first place with plenty of their gluten-free injera to go around (see photo). Injera is the spongy flatbread that may look like remnants of a yoga mat but is actually handmade from teff with an unusually vinegary flavor. I like it. Since I'm eating less red meat these days, I honed in on the $11.95 Doro Wot, which is a dish consisting of a couple of chicken drumsticks and a hard-boiled egg all slathered in an Ethiopian chili stew.

I usually stay away from chicken-and-egg combos simply because of the implied mother-and-child allusion. Seriously. I just think it's weird to combine poultry at different stages of its life on one plate. But I got over it since it was tasty nicely complemented by a side house salad and the injera (see photo). One interesting twist is that you have to say you want it "family-style" if you want the food served more traditionally on the injera fully rolled out on a platter. Otherwise, you get it Western style on a regular plate. On the side, I also went for a $3.95 bowl of Kin-Che, a couscous-like rice with a buttery taste that probably didn't help with my personal curbing of the carbs (see photo).

Fana serves sandwiches and stews to go in addition to the mid-priced entrees. The lamb of the Ye Beg Wot appears to be gone from their menu, but they now have chicken breast, steak tartare and tofu options. Listen, she and her family are very nice and obviously close-knit. Friends of theirs came by while I was eating, and you can just tell. You should definitely give Moya a try in their new digs. They obviously went through a lot this past year, and I think it's great they were committed to staying in SoMa instead of moving to the 'burbs where rents are likely cheaper. If you haven't tried Fana's homestyle Ethiopian food, you need to give it a go.

FOOD - 4 stars...still the same flavorful, homestyle Ethiopian fare served up before their relocation
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a bit more fast-foody than before but warmed by their artwork
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very nice people
TOTAL - 4 stars...Moya is back and here to stay, I hope
author: Ed U.

description: not so great neighborhood but a fantastic lunch spot - their berbere sauce is not too spicy and the injera is spot on. They give you huge portions so you are really buying for two meals. I would recommend doing a take out as this place gets insanely hot inside! I am happy I found a nice Ethiopian place for when my craving hits
author: Sree S.

description:
Really good. The spices are fantastic and the lentils are well-cooked.

Moya is great food for an excellent price. I ordered two veggie combos for two people and we ended up barely finishing the food. It ended up being less than $40 for two people for lunch. We were so full that we didn't eat dinner.

The only issue was that the carrots were a little underdone for my liking but I can see why they leave them a little on the raw side.

I gave them five-stars because it's an amazing value. Would definitely eat there again.
author: Mel C.

description:
I always want to try Ethiopian food because I read review that their food are healthy . I never knew what to order .So, I went there with my Ethiopian friend . We order a veggie platter and a beef platter for three of us . He taught us how to eat it with our fingers . ( not bad ). 
Food is good and I am glad I try it . The bad part was after I left the restaurant , the clothes smell really strong ,
author: Isabelle L.

description:
I came here today 15 minutes before they were closing. I quickly ordered and was in and out in under 5 minutes. 

Veggie Sample with Injera ($12.95): 
I ordered it to go and it came with a side salad. The injera was wrapped in foil and the vegetables were stuffed in a microwave safe box. Let's just say that presentation was not the best. 

The food itself was quite bland and drowning in oil. Probably the most oily thing I have ever eaten in my life. The collared greens are what I disliked the most. They were really bitter and sour at the same time. I found myself eating the injera with the side salad instead of the actual entree (it's surprisingly super yummy). The stews and potatoes were meh. I've had better.
author: Anna H.

description:
Ate good Ethiopian food after a long time. The veggie sampler was absolutely delicious and reminded me of what Asmara in the East Bay used to taste like a few years ago. 


The spicy red lentil stew was just the right level of spice and the yellow lentil was just the right level of bland without losing its flavor. Not a huge fan of the green beans and cabbage stew, but fine! The collard green could have been chopped a wee bit finer but didn't lack in the taste department. 

This is certainly going to be my go-to for Ethiopian food in the future!
author: Rakesh L.

description: This restaurant is spectacular! I can't believe I waited this long to try it. I had the vegetarian stewed chickpea ... the name does not do this dish justice. It was delicious, flavorful, inexpensive and prepared in a reasonable amount of time. I will be coming back here again and again!!
author: Laurence S.

description: One of the best Ethiopian I've had yet!! It's a cafe style so it's kind of informal. You order in the front and then they bring out your food. I got the veggie sampler for a lunch special and it was soooo much food for such a good deal! About $9 for my plate of salad, red lentils, yellow lentils, collard greens, and this potato/carrot/green bean/cabbage thing. Very tasty! The injerah was also super soft and didn't brittle up like it normally does! I'll be back to try the meat dishes!
author: Diane H.

description: This is more like a fast-food Ethiopian joint. The flavors aren't great because they taste watered-down. I'll just go to my regular favorite instead of this place.
author: Suzi G.

description: I got the vegetarian sampler and I'm so full right now.Good serving size. Lots of the injera (bread). So much I couldn't finish. I stopped by right around 11:30 to beat the rush. Sweet service. Price was $14 plus $2 tip. But that's about what you'd pay at any of the food trucks in "Soma Street Food Park" with way better quantity and quality.
author: Megan D.

description:
Really good find in SOMA! 

One of my girlfriends picked me up from work and we were en route to a theater rehearsal when I mentioned we probably ought to pick up some food and this was her suggestion. I love, love love Ethiopian food and at that point I hadn't had it in quite some time so we stopped off here. 

I ordered my usual, the Doro Tibs, and a side of Injera - and out of curiosity (but also because I knew I would be sharing) I also ordered Tofu Tibs. The Doro Tibs was out of this world, and while the Tofu Tibs was flavorful, it just reminded me of sauteed tofu - don't know why I thought it would be fried or something. 

I will definitely come back and order more food. Maybe eat in though - the bag they gave me for take-out got a little greasy.
author: Aivy C.

description:
Yum - so good!

My friend went later in the evening on a Friday night (they close at 9, though I think that's when they stop taking orders). We ordered the vegetarian sampler and the doro tibs. The vegetarian sampler is enough for two people, but the doro tibs were worth the feeling of overwhelming full-ness. In addition to the doro tibs, the yellow pea stew was another standout. You get a ton of injera with your entree so no need to order it separately.

The restaurant has a cafe feel - bright lights, order at the counter - and only  6-8 tables.

Moya is really reasonably-priced - only ~$25-30 for dinner for the two of us!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Awesome Ethiopian food! Happened upon this place on accident - best unexpected discovery. Got one of the samplers which is plenty of food. Now I work nearby (SoMa-loin) & can't wait to go back soon.

Neighborhood ambiance is obviously rough around the edges, not sure if they are open for dinner but lunch is a great time to go.
author: E F.

description:
So glad I stumbled upon this place! Trying Ethiopian has been on the list of things to do (amongst everything else on the planet...) and I finally got to tackle that notion today... 

From the outside, Moya is easy to miss. It's got no official sign outside (that I am aware of anyway...), but has a menu posted outside of it's doors. The only thing that stood out to me the most was the very shiny, silver exterior of their space and the address # 121 posted across the windows. 

If you have never been, ordering is done at the counter pre-dining. You walk through the small spaced, yet immaculate dining area, up to the sleek and chic counter to order and pay in advance. They then will bring your order out to your table after. 

I got the Lunch Vegetarian Platter which took only a few minutes to make. I would definitely do this if you've never had this style of food before... and aren't sure what to get. 

These days, their Veg Platter consists of 
Injera Bread- traditional Ethiopian bread (kind of sour) or Rice or Gluten-free bread
with 
~Misir Wot- red lentil stew
~Kik Ali-Cha - yellow pea stew
~Gomen - sauteed collard greens
~curried potatoes, carrots and seasonal vegetables  (forget the Ethiopian name for this one)
and a bite sized house salad

It was a plate full of food, but all very small proportions, making it just the right amount for one person with a good appetite. 

I think I'm in love with Ethiopian food after my experience here. It's similar to South Indian food, the way it is served and the level of spiciness. It's an ideal spot for vegetarians (surprised it took me so long to get here!)
author: Cassandra E.

description:
I hadn't liked Ethiopian food the first time I tried it, but liked it here.

Ordered the veggie sampler +  sigga tibs (sauteed beef) on injera served traditional style. Enough for two people, with leftovers.

Clean, modern looking decor. Not a whole lot of seating. Good place for small groups, 1:1 conversations/catch-ups.

Friendly service!
author: An Y.

description: I really like this place for lunch. Super fresh, delicious vegetarian combo & great injera-also they offer gluten free injera & brown rice options.
author: Rude A.

description: It's hard to figure out how to order around here. Not very customizable. Makes me miss South Africa.
author: Krystal A.

description: Really good Ethiopian food. I really enjoyed the selection and it the vegetarian platter was large enough to share between me and a friend. I would definitely come again. Service was friendly and fast as well.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Cute little place- we stopped in before catching Newsies at the Orpheum Theatre. I love ethiopian food- eat it all time. I hadn't been here before- and I was a little disappointed to see that they don't have a liquor license... no honey wine! They did have gluten-free injera, great for the hubby, and the vegetarian combo platter is what we ordered. 

It was good, but not as flavorful as I would have wanted.
author: Kate B.

description:
I just want MOYA!

We came here on the way out of the city, having not eaten since our gluttonous but unregrettable breakfast of homemade cinnamon roll pancakes (that's right, be jealous)... I was starving and couldn't wait until we got home to eat.  So we ended up here, having talked about getting Ethiopian food for the past few weeks.

It's owned by a friendly family.  The prices are more than reasonable, the ambience is that industrial San Francisco feel that totally works in SoMA... But more than anything, we need to talk about the food.

The food, habibi.  It's the business.  We got the veggie sampler and the tofu tibs, and while we can usually agree on one menu item in situations like these that doesn't match up to the rest-- but not here.  It was all standout-delicious in its own way and totally conducive to mixing.  The injera was fresh and perfect, with that characteristic sour bite.  And apparently I've learned to eat Ethiopian food in a way that it doesn't expand so uncomfortably in my stomach.  Such a pro!
author: Allison M.

description:
Most of vegetarian dishes in the sampler were pretty yummy, though some of them were a little light on flavor. The chicken was like the standard restaurant supply stuff - not tender, nor did it absorb much of the spices. They were out of doro wot, so maybe that was better quality. The service was just OK. The prices were reasonable.

It's a good spot for a quick bite if you're in SoMa but if you want more authentic or higher quality, there are probably better options.
author: Blair S.

description:
This place is a diamond in the rough.

I brought a non-city dweller here and hadn't been before myself. The walk from the 47 was...colorful. But when we saw Moya in the distance, I had a good feeling. We had the lunch vegetarian special and it was delicious. Every bite. And we cleared our plates. The young lady running things is a doll and even offered for us to try something we hadn't ordered simply because she made a little too much for another customer. Love it!

The only thing I didn't like was that there were large slow moving flies hanging around. Maybe close the doors and windows and turn on the air?

Regardless--I will be back for more. Yuuuuuum.
author: James S.

description:
I dined at Moya for an industry mixer event. It's located on a busy street in SOMA where you'd least expect a restaurant, and is rather small - fitting it's peculiar location.

Definitely not up to par with regard to some of the more established Ethiopian places in SF and the East Bay, but it's okay for what it is. 

Many of the items on the vegetarian platter were rather cold when we received them, so that was slightly unappetizing. Flavors were okay, but again, nothing memorable.

Okay to grab a quick bite in a neighborhood that lacks eateries, but otherwise skippable if you're in SF.
author: Mansi A.

description: My eyes were burning from the onions in the air but pretty good lunch spot with staff.
author: Steph N.

description: I love this place.  Food is beyond delicious, prices are fair and the service is great!  It gets very busy and crowded at times, but definitely worth checking out if you're in the area!
author: E M.

description:
I don't know if it's my exceptionally high standards when it comes to Ethiopian food, or whether it's my multiple awesome experiences at Zeni in SJ that killed every other Ethiopian's restaurants experience, that makes me feel Moya leaves a lot to be desired.

Yeah, it isn't all that fancy, ergo, none of the Ethiopian decor flaff or a pianist belting out loud music while you dine (think Sheba). Moya is just your quintessential cafe that serves Ethiopian food on the side (or that's how I felt about the establishment)

We ordered a vegetarian platter family style, to be split between the hubs and I. Along with a bottle of Bundaberg (who can say no to Bundaberg when it's right there!?). And let me tell you, the only thing I thoroughly enjoyed during my meal, was the Bundaberg (and that came at a price too, $6 for a bottle. As you can see, I am still trying to come to terms with paying 2x for everything in the city) 

The food was cold. The yellow peas, the red lentil stew were cold (and lacking flavor), the collard greens tasted a bit bitter than what I am used to. The cabbage/carrot/potato curry was phenomenal and the injera was sour to perfection. Saving grace was the injera. 

Price wise, it was reasonable by SF standards. I just don't think I'll come back since it truly wasn't a memorable meal.
author: Ranjani S.

description:
So I'm starting on a new quest to be more adventurous in my lunch outings and use my bike to get to places around town I wouldn't normally go to. Moya was on the list and I was able to hit it up on my way into work. At opening time the place was super quiet - I was the only one there. The two ladies were super nice and though I felt bad about making them cook for me when no one else was there they seemed unperturbed. I got the ingudai ribs, medium hot, to go with some injera. What wasn't so great was the crazy homeless person outside who asked me for food then blocked the doorway the entire time - not letting me leave. The owner had to call the police to come clear the way. Luckily the guy left on his own and I hustled out. 

By the time I got to work the sauce had spilled out of the the container and made a mess even though it was double-bagged. NOTE: bring your own leak proof container or don't walk very far. Despite all this the ingudai ribs were pretty awesome. There's no other way to describe them. Sautéed mushrooms, nicely spicy, pretty spicy in fact. Nom nom nom. The injera is a nicely rolled up round. Perfect for scooping up the ingudai ribs. I don't know how they do this but they give you the perfect amount of injera for eating up the food.
author: Jean K.

description: I absolutely love this spot. Great small family owned business in SoMa with very friend staff and great food. Nothing warms you up on a cold day like the Doro Tibs, and the house made cheese is a great accent to any dish.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
My friend and I stumbled upon this place by accident while looking for a warm place to duck in for a bit around Market St. She had never had Ethiopian food and it's one of my favorite cuisines so I figured we'd both enjoy Moya.

The restaurant can be a bit confusing in terms of how you order and are seated. Despite all the people who might be sitting at tables around you, you do have to order your food up front and pay first before seating yourself. The staff will bring out the food to you, but they don't exactly wait on you like in traditional restaurants. It's very cafeteria-style.

We got the Veggie Sampler (misir wot, kik alicha, gomen, atkiliti wot) and the kitfo. Everything was exceptionally tasty and well-cooked. The kitfo has a definite kick to it that builds as time goes on, so don't order this if you are sensitive to spiciness. Out of all the veggie entrees, I think the gomen was the best. The injera was one of the least "soggy"-feeling ones I've ever had but had all of that delicious sourness you expect. I was initially worried that they wouldn't provide enough injera for the two of us, but it turned out to be plenty. In fact, we had more than enough to take home for leftovers. Injera heats up so well in the microwave, because it already has a naturally soggy texture so the moisture from the heat doesn't really affect it.

The space is very new and sleek 'n' chic, as I like to describe modern aesthetics. And I have to rave about the staff. Some of the nicest people I have ever encountered. They were so warm, welcoming and accommodating to us. They seemed genuinely concerned that we enjoyed the food and went out of their way to make sure everything was to our liking. Very sweet.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I came here for dinner with my husband and we ordered two veggie samplers. We were led to believe on the menu stuck to the window that each veggie sampler was $9.95. However, when we went in to the cash register, it ended up costing $12.95. 

As a matter of principle, I queried this as it is deceptive and misleading advertising. I was not disputing the price, as the server was arguing with me, but I was asking why they had advertised the incorrect price for the meal. All other restaurants can advertise the correct price on their menu!!

The server responded that they had just put the wrong menu out, however like I explained, that is not my error. Moya (like all restuarants, cafes, bars, pubs etc) should have the CORRECT price advertised on their menu's, otherwise it is deceptive and misleading to the customer.

Moya, just so you are all aware in the United States, there are state and federal false advertising laws that prohibit various types of deceptive advertising, misleading labeling, and related practices. False advertising laws provide important rights for consumers and competitors, arming them with the ability to seek redress when they've been overcharged unlawfully.

An advertisement is a message that promotes a product or a service or gives information to the public. Advertisements may take many forms; such as press advertisements in newspapers or magazines, television and radio advertisements or SIGNS and MENUS in SHOPS.

Misleading advertising means advertising that deceives or is likely to deceive anyone that sees it. Misleading advertising may affect consumers' choices regarding what they buy, such as advertising a meal for $9.95 when the amount charged is $12.95. It's worth bearing in mind, that it may be an offence for a trader to advertise good or services if it is likely to mislead and therefore cause loss (financial or otherwise) to the public.

The server then began arguing that the price was $12.95 so I used an example... would you go to a store and buy a coke advertised for $1.00 then when you go to pay for it, you are charged $2.00? Would you be happy that the incorrect price was advertised? Or would you pay the $2.00 and be happy with the fact you were misled by a false price? When I mentioned this to the server, she became more irate and asked us to leave.......... and  short changing us, we had paid $30 for our two meals and the server refunded $21

Clearly being dishonest and unethical is more important than good customer service.

In summary, Moya;

1. Deceptive and misleading advertising on their menus - prices are incorrect, you need to correct the prices. If a meal is $12.95 it should be $12.95 on the menu and NOT $9.95
2. Short change people - a refund is the FULL amount. I paid $30 not $21
3. Unethical business practice and dishonest
4. No apology was offered, staff were rude

Please read:
California's False Advertising Law and California's Consumers Legal Remedies Act


Dishonest conduct - shame on you, Moya.
author: Alice T.

description: One of my favorite, healthy dining options in SF. Veggie sampler and Kitfo with collard greens is the way to go. Make sure you ask for medium spicy if you like your tastebuds.
author: Jeremie H.

description:
I'm in downtown SF looking for a good place to eat and Yelp comes up and tells me there's an Ethiopian restaurant not far from the hotel I'm stay at. I'm ready to go.

Lets start with the walk there.  Not knowing the city, I walked down 6th street, bad idea. That was the only street that was "questionable" all throughout the city. Saw some interesting "business" deals and some colorful characters, but once I got to Folsom, it was fine.  So, I would avoid Market and 6th to 6th and Folsom.

However, the food makes up for everything. The food was fantastic, very authentic as well.  No surprise, the chef is the owner and it shows with how much love and dedication is placed into getting it right. The waitress, daughter of the owner, came over and brought us some samples of Injera without gluten and that it's more authentic.  You should definitely try it if you haven't had it before.

We had the vegetarian combination and everyone was delicious, full of flavor and FRESH.

I highly recommend Moya, but recommend taking a different route there.  Enjoy!
author: Randy G.

description:
I was looking for a great Ethiopian restaurant when I found Moya.  When I googled mapped it, I realized it's only 5 blocks from my house, PERFECT!   So this place gets 4 stars for the 100% teff injera alone!  Mmmmm, it was so good.  So nutty and flavorful compared to regular injera, totally worth the extra $2.  The food tasted very healthy, not oily at all compared with other Ethiopian restaurants I've been to.  

My husband and I ordered everything vegan!  Here is the review:

Veggie Sampler:  This did not exactly match the online menu.  It came with MISIR WOT (red lentil) which was sooooooooo good, just the right spiciness level for me. And not oily at all! Hooray!  It also had KIK ALI-CHA (yellow pea).  I didn't like this one, it was completely bland, not even a touch of flavor.  My husband liked it .  But i think This one really could have used some extra kick.  GOMEN (collard greens), again, not a ton of flavor.  There was also a potato/carrot dish.  This one is a common dish in all ethiopian restaurants.  It tasted to me like it always does.  There was also a nice little salad with this plate.  Refreshing.  

Suro:  This was a chickpea stew with 15 spices.  It had a great flavor (right in between the lentil and pea dishes in terms of spiciness).  It had a very creamy consistency though. 

INGUDAI TIBS:  Mushrooms. The kind waitress brought this dish out for free when she saw how much we were enjoying the food.  This had an excellent flavor!  A good kick to it with the jalapeño.  It was really good. 

I think they could do a bit better job on the decor.  They are in a brand new building, and the whole place just felt a little too sterile and new.  

I wish they had an Ocra dish on the menu, but they're a small shop, so I understand that they have to draw the line somewhere.

I'll be back for sure!!!  I have a feeling I'm going to be a regular for the red lentil dish and 100% teff injera.
author: Evelyn N.

description:
So this was my first experience with Ethiopian food and it was great!  The menu was easy to navigate and the owner was uber friendly!

We decided to grab dinner at Moya on our way to the Orpheum, since it was a) nearby and b) a quick meal.  We ended up finding street parking out front, and was able to park there all night (during the show), which made everything a perfect fit.

It's a small cafe that can seat just under 50 people.  You order at the counter first, then they bring your food out to you.  Between two of us, we ordered the Veggie sampler and Doro Tibs, which was just the right amount of food.  Our meal was served on one large plate, over Injera, with a separate plate of Injera served to us, as well.  We both had hearty appetites, and still somehow managed to have a few bites left over.

Overall, I had a good experience and food was good.  Will I go back? Maybe if I'm in the area... It was definitely a quick option, for a meal before going to the Orpheum.

All in all, I'd say 3.5 stars.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Celiacs, beware. I tried out Moya because of the reviews here for gluten-free injera, and ended up losing my entire dinner in the toilet later that night. 

Last month I ordered takeout for 4 via their mobile app, and the nice lady who handed me the food reassured me in person that the injera was gluten-free. There must have been a mix-up in the kitchen, though, because I have never had that strong a reaction to food that had less than A LOT of gluten in it. None of my non-celiac companions had digestive trouble.

Additionally, Moya omitted one of the veggie dishes I had ordered and pre-paid for, which underlines the theory of communication trouble in the kitchen.

That said, the food was delicious. We had the special version of the beef dish and the chicken with mushrooms. I might give it another shot, only I'll stick with the rice and maybe eat-in instead of take-out.
author: Hilary C.

description:
Moya, aother "find" within walking distance of my office, ethiopian is a fun alternative for lunch. Today I was joined by a fellow artist (painter), paralegal-by-day. He's also got some wild stories. WOW. Always fun.

I ordered the kitfo, a beef tartare with clarified butter. You heard me correctly. This was accompanied by salad, KIK ALI-CHA (yellow pea stew) and the ingira bread. The first bites of the tartare were amazing but be warned, this is heavy stuff. They give you a lot of it and I wasn't able to finish it. It's really rich. The salad does help to cut that richness but in itself, was unremarkable. My friend had a grilled chicken with ethiopian spices and enjoyed it a lot. He too felt we got a lot of food for our buck. The menu does cater to american tastes, and is not as broad as I've found at other ethiopian restaurants. It is quick though, and perfect for a well executed, nontypical lunch.
author: Mark N.

description: It was not a good experience for me, I  been to multiple Ethiopian and Eritean  restaurants. They don't even put Injera, Sponge bread Underneath the food. It didn't look right it didn't taste right and it wasn't served right. I know how it should taste and I know how it should be served. And it's not right.. That's all..
author: Isaac Y.

description:
Bring your family, bring your kids. Bring everyone. There are two places where you shouldn't eat alone -- a Korean restaurant and an Ethiopian.

The five of us walked up to the counter and ordered three dishes. Somehow, the other two forgot at some point, and as the five of us sat to converse a large platter of richly flavored meats and veggies came out, as well as soft, spongy rolled up rice pancakes.

Most amazingly, the meal filled five pretty hungry, pretty buzzed individuals. Never had family style quite like this place, but I'll definitely bringing friends here again.
author: Christophe C.

description: Ok I would have given this restaurant a better review had it not been for their horrible customer service! I ordered food from Eat24 food hadn't arrived after 1.5 hours despite me being 4 blocks from the restaurant.  Phoned restaurant and they said "well Eat24 delivers the food" and if you call and "complain" they will give you a a free meal.  Ummm I don't want a free meal! I want my delivery within the estimated delivery time frame and ALSO I want someone to take accountability, I mean your business utilizes Eat24 perhaps they should rethink that business relationship, I won't be back.
author: James E.

description:
My first time having Ethiopian food and it was pure awesome! We came here and shared a pretty big platter - I can't even remember everything that we ordered but there was doro wot involved and it was delicious. Seems to be a pretty legit place in the area, and while it's not a fancy sit down restaurant, you can probably come here for lunch or dinner and leave with a satisfied tummy.

Be warned - if you're looking for a cab in the area, you may be looking for a good 30 minutes. Either call a cab ahead of time, or try checking out Lyft or Uber unless you want to be standing outside for a while trying to hail anything in your way.
author: Lalida S.

description:
So good! I am a big fan of Ethiopian food and usually eat out in Oakland. But we wanted injera and good flavors in San Francisco so we tried Moya. What a treat! The vegetarian sampler was entirely delicious and interesting, the Doro Tibs were fantastic, well-seasoned and not greasy at all. The smells from the kitchen were mouth-watering - I'm looking forward to trying more.

The atmosphere was more coffee shop than slow dining but courtesy of Yelp we knew that going in. The staff was warm and welcoming and the extra large Mexican sodas in glass bottles was the perfect touch.
author: Holly F.

description: There are not a lot of Ethiopian restaurants in San Francisco. So I was glad to find this hidden gem  in Civic Center/Soma area. I usually get the beef tibs with injeria and ayab cheese with their house salad. A little pricey around $16 for entree but always good. I'm a loyal customer.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Before I discovered Moya I was sure that Oakland and San Jose had the only good Ethiopian restaurants in the Bay Area, but now I've found a place that can satisfy my cravings in San Francisco.

The two best things about Moya are the kitfo and the injera.  The injera is all teff, so it's gluten free and a gorgeous color.  It's very flavorful and sour. The kitfo is only served raw and is incredible. I'm not as big of a fan of the veggie combo or doro tibs.
author: Jackie B.

description:
I left a review for this restaurant before that addressed the practice of them charging for injera. They must follow their Yelp reviews and considered my points valid, and they began providing injera with the meals. Charging for the injeras was my only real complaint as it was tantamount to charging for chopsticks in a Chinese restaurant or a fork at any other restaurant. I'm happy to say that their business model for charging for the injera seems to have improved to a more reasonable model. 

I will say that they are great on customer service here. My boyfriend's iPhone was dying, and they allowed us to use their iPad charger from their iPad/Square/register setup. This is going above and beyond. 

Thank you again for adjusting the charging for injera to complimentary with a meal.
author: dAvid s.

description:
The new location for Moya is much more upscale and sleek than some of the photos here would lead you to believe, since they just reopened about 3 weeks ago.

This Ethiopian restaurant is actually one of the few places in SF that's open before 4pm or 5pm.  If you have a hankering like we sometimes do, this may be your only option, but it's still a good one.  The service is pleasant and it's actually easy to take your food to go if you need to leave.  The fruit infused water is a nice touch and I like that they have self-serve silverware (I know that you traditionally eat with your hands, but sometimes that just isn't feasible).  We were happy with the quality of the food and will definitely come back.
author: Dylan T.

description:
I don't give out 5 stars unless i mean it and I do. Gluten free injera, veggie sampler (of course) spiced so deliciously. And super friendly staff.
The restaurant itself is a bit cold feeling with the warehousy vibe, but the food is too good to care.
author: Krista H.

description:
This place is really nice and different. The food was one of the different things that I tried and I will go back for it. Emmm the bread makes everything enjoyable. 
I had shero and vegi sample and baklava on the house   the kids loved it and enjoyed the staff that they were so nice and lovely.
author: Jean M.

description: I love this place! We generally get the Veggie Sampler and add Siga Tibs (the Doro Tibs is also out of this world). Between the delicious food and friendly staff, Moya has become one of our favorite spots in SF.
author: Russ M.

description: A good place for home cooking!  This was my first experience with Ethopian so I guess this is now the bench mark.  Doro tibs, Siga tibs, and Kitfo are all very good.  Just a simple place to grab a good bite.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Authentic Ethiopian food that still feels like a small family run business and not a commercial establishment. You can ask for you food to  be mild, medium or spicy. Beware that the spicy food can be really spicy. So if you like your food fiery hot, go ahead and ask her to make it spicy. 

Only complaint would be that the business hours are quite short and they are shut on Sundays. But otherwise, would recommend this small restaurant to everyone.

I would recommend the Siga Tibs (meat) or the Inguada Tibs (mushrooms) depending if you eat meat or not. Definitely try it with Injara (slightly sour bread)
author: Shringar P.

description:
One visit so far. Takeout, called in by phone. Takeout service was quick and efficient.

I got the doro tibs (chicken stew), ordered spicy, with an added side of the kik alicha (yellow split pea stew) (or was it shiro?). Small salad and injera were included.

Verdict: Some of the better Ethiopian I've had. (Note, this is based on sampling only two dishes, so far.) I typically eat from places in Oakland that are solid (and there are many). 

The chicken wasn't overcooked, and it had a flavorful, well-spiced clarified butter sauce. The split peas were firm (al dente?), not mushy, and thankfully not bland, either--the most common issues I find with this dish at other places.

The injera portion could have been larger, but on the bright side, it prevented me from overeating and having to teff out the afternoon in an uncomfortable state. (Yeah, that's an Ethiopian food pun.)

Prices aren't cheap, but I'll still be returning because I'm willing to pay for the quality, and I don't have other nearby Ethiopian lunch options, anyway.
author: Chris Z.

description:
Quality Ethiopian food, ideal prices, great location, parking is surprisingly great given the location. 

My wife is vegan and I am pescatarian so we do have specific dietary restrictions and this place not only meets but exceeds. 

The service is pleasant and consistent even during rush hours, I highly recommend.
author: D T.

description:
Spectacular spot! I took a group of middle school students here and the owner was so gracious; she even came to talk to the kids about the food and how to eat it. We also took a photo together! I'd post the photo if I was better at technology but I assure you all it's a beautiful sight to see local business owners who care about kids in the community! 

The food was also in huge portions and crazy delicious! Moyà you are a beacon of awesome in a vastly changing city; thank you so much for your commitment to the lives and experiences of these youth.
author: Lawrence F.

description:
Popped in here on the way to see an event at the Thrill-peddlers on 10th

We had the vegetarian  platter

It was  enough for the two of us and we really liked it. Especially the spicy red lentils

I love the crepe like bread and also the  collard greens, the dh not so much.  He like the yellow  pea  dish.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Good place, affordable, good service and good food. What more ? It says vegan but the menu has both vegan and non vegetarian options
author: Ash L.

description: Food was great, service not so much. The restaurant was supposed to open at 5pm on a Monday afternoon but the doors were still closed at 5:20pm and calls went to their voicemail. When I returned at 5:50pm, the place was finally open. I had the Doro Tibs and it was fantastic - flavorful, non-greasy, generous portion.
author: Eeva I.

description:
Great place for vegetarians. I like the mushroom tibs and the yellow lentils. Get it spicy. It is tasty indeed. You can have it with brown rice or the sour bread. 

Don't mind the weirdos outside. The place inside is good, clean and delicious.
author: Margaret S.

description:
I adore Moya. The food is excellent and the people who run it are kind. I order different dishes every time I go based on the company, sometimes with vegetarians, sometimes with meat eaters.
