The menu is flexible this way. Order one order of injera and ask for forks. Eat the remainder of the food with the injera on the bottom of the platter. Personal fav is the vegetarian platter and the doro wot. 

My favorite place in the city to get Ethiopian food. It's centrally located, takes square and it's worth it.
author: Ami K.

description:
TIP #1: Order at the counter, sit down, and enjoy the calm atmosphere before digging in!

TIP #2: You can choose the spiciness level of each dish, but if you order multiple dishes, they'll come out on the same platter. So beware.

Never write a review while hungry. Here I am, stomach grumbling, drooling on the keyboard--

My boyfriend and I ordered two dishes for dinner on a Wednesday evening: one with sauteed mushrooms, and one with chicken drumsticks and an egg. Both dishes, as well as their accompanying side salads, arrived on a large, injera-lined platter. The mushrooms were very juicy and tasted fresh. The chicken drumsticks were tender, and the spice had permeated the meat to give it a delicious flavor. We switched between using the injera and our forks to transport bite after bite into our hungry mouths. When the main dishes were done, we couldn't help but pick at the injera on the platter that had soaked up all the yummy juices from the mushrooms and chicken.

You can read and imagine, but it's nothing like going to Moya and experiencing it for yourself. Likewise, I can try to relive that dinner through this review... I will likely return when I crave Ethiopian food in the city again.
author: A.L. H.

description:
I didn't know what Kitfo was until I went here, now I can't wait to try it again.

African eateries often get overlooked here in The City, but this is one that shouldn't be dismissed. It's really a simple coffee bar-style place with windows to look out on the world. But whether you're there for three minutes or 30, your time will be well-spent.
author: Charles L.

description: Best vegan Ethiopian dishes in North America (out of the 20+ places I've eaten - including DC!) amazing flavours and variety. the first time I've seen tofu or mushroom tibs on a menu and I'll be craving both until I return to SF. super friendly and accommodating staff. when I ate there they had just returned from Eithiopia with spices - which they blend themselves - for truly original flavours. both of the above tibs were cooked to order and I was given the choice of spice level. gluten free injera available. dead animal options also available.
author: Lentil C.

description:
Wait? There's an Ethiopian place near here?

That's where we're going then!

The restaurant Moya is well lit, but still slightly dusky giving them fantastic ambiance. They also have plenty of seating in their well laid out restaurant and the service is quick and personable. For my injera cravings I now head here where they boast both fabulous injera and gursha, the kik alitcha being my favrouite.

The only negatives in my book, which are probably positives to some, it that their door is wheelchair accessible, thus it stays open for several minutes after automatically opening. This simply means if you sit next to the door, it'll be chilly. They also don't take cash.

To me, this just means I now sit in the back and bring a billfold... or coin purse. I mean, I gotta spend those Caltrain coins somewhere's now don't I?
author: Meg T.

description:
I recently came here after being here 2 years ago

My meal for the veggie sampler was $8.50 two years ago (I still have the receipt), this time my bill was $15.00

That's ridiculous. That's almost a 200% increase in 2 years

This is not worth a 200% increase
author: Brandon J.

description:
What an awesome addition to my lunch routine. A friend came up with the idea of having Ethiopean food for lunch and suggested Moya. I am so glad he did. I enjoy the spicy full flavored food from Ethiopia and what they serve at Moya is super authentic and delicious at the same time. 

I had the Doro Wot, my friend had the Doro Tibs. Both delicious, spicy and bold but not overpowering. I'll definitely come back soon to try out the other items on the menu. Especially the vegetarian sampler... saying that, I wish there was a meat dish sampler, because everything sounds yummy and I had a hard time making a decision.
author: Tobias G.

description: Came here 25 minutes before closing to pick up some food,  lots of people inside, eating, but door was locked and sign said Closed. Maybe if I catch them when they're open I'll have a good experience. For now I guess it's just one of those places that closes when they feel like it, and that I can't trust will be open during their scheduled hours.
author: Michael S.

description:
This place is yummy! It's Moroccan style were you eat with your hands, but it's completely different flavors.... Ethiopian! 

No those are not hand towels on your plate, but a spongy sourdough flatbread that you can use to make mini raps. 

They'll deliver the food to your table but you'll have to get own flatware and napkins. It's got a clean, but simple dining area but the bathroom is a bit dirty.
author: Naomi C.

description:
The food is reeeeeeeeally good and with good portion. 

The reason that is a 4 star rather than 5 is because of its popularity, hence the slight long wait.

Highly recommended.
author: Lo Y.

description:
Great find on 9th. It's a clean small restaurant that serves up delicious Ethiopian food. All of the dishes are to be shared and come with injera and salad. I had the chicken with mushrooms, veggie sampler and mushrooms. If you want spicy, they can make it very spicy!!!

Service was great considering you order at the counter and seat yourselves. They also have a highchair if you need it. 

Definitely on our list of SF staples.
author: Natalie S.

description: Fantastic hearty well spiced Ethiopian food. I like trying everything so the sampler plate was perfect for me. Bring an appetite, because the portions are large.
author: Christina M.

description:
Since finding this place a month ago, I've been four times. It's insanely good, and is a perfect business.

What's your angle? Do you like small, local businesses? Well, the waitress is the daughter and granddaughter of the mother and grandmother who are cooking in the kitchen. It doesn't get much more "real people" than that.

Plus, there's an ongoing Soma War. Keeping business doors open is essential to preventing the druggies and criminals from overrunning SOMA again. In 2003, SOMA was a lot like the Tenderloin. In 2010, it's civilized....As long as you stay in after 10:30 p.m. or so. Supporting local businesses is essential for the neighborhood.

Social critique aside, the food is awesome. It's also affordable. Four of us ate there - tons of food (depicted in a picture I uploaded), as it was a table of big eaters. With tip, we got out of there for $80.

There are gluten-free options. I prefer the taste of the teff. This Wikipedia entry is helpful: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eragrostis_tef

I've had the lamb, chicken, kitfo (you can get it cooked if you don't ' want to eat raw ground beef), and kitfo special (cheese and collard greens are mixed in with the kitfo), and lentils. Everything has been fantastic.

I've ordered carry out, too. (Picture uploaded.) Huge servings. I ate it all, plus almost all of the ye doro tibs. For more on the ye dora tibs, see this SF Weekly article:
http://blogs.sfweekly.com/foodie/2010/07/spicy_ethiopian_chicken_at_moy.php

Moya is a new favorite that I'll be taking all of my friends to.
author: Michael C.

description: Not usually the biggest fan of Ethiopian, but I really dug this place for take out. So many distinct flavors - and well balanced. Fresh veggies, perfectly cooked. I'd definitely return.
author: Andrew K.

description:
We stumbled into Moya on accident, hungry and drawn to the relatively high reviews compared to other eateries in the area. 

We ordered the garbanzo curry and the house special kitfo. 

Our injera (all teff) was pleasantly tart and springy. The kitfo was tender and tasted okay, but lacked some of the nuances of spiced butter that make this dish one I usually crave. Similarly, the garbanzo curry was spicy (in itself good - we like it hot), but besides the chili burn there was some layers of flavor missing from this dish. The dressing on the salad tasted way too vinegary for my taste. 

The injera was my favorite element of the meal, and while the other items seemed fresh, well presented, and good enough, they were also somewhat unsatisfying compared to the Ethiopian food I've had elsewhere.
author: Monica S.

description: I was pretty excited about going to the place but walked out less than impressed. Nothing was really wrong, per say, but the service was quite sub par and the food was underwhelming. I have eaten my fair share of Ethiopian in my day and it used to be my favorite cuisine. However, somehow this felt more like fast food than the authentic spices I am accustomed to. Infact, the veggie platter that was so well reviewed tasted like microwaved refried beans from a can and daal from a packet. All that said, the injera was fantastic and the place was quite clean (except for the wooden germ-laden bathroom key).  I hope I just got the disinterested servers on a bad day but I won't be running back anytime soon.
author: Carmella L.

description:
Dinner at Moya is a bit more quiet than during lunch time I would assume.  They are cafe style, you order - pay -sit down and wait for your food.  Which works nicely if you are with a friend and worrying about how you are going to split the bill.  

Their selection was extensive, they give you the option for family style.  Which means you can order all the food you want and they will join everything together onto one plate.  We wanted to order this beef dish and the lady who worked there (who was the cashier, cook, waitress) asked us if we have had Ethiopian before and when we said yes asked if we had that dish before.  Recommended that we tried another beef dish, because she explained that this dish takes some "getting used to" and to be safe if we wanted to enjoy our dinner should order something "safer".  That works for me, much appreciated that she points this out dispute how busy she was cooking and doing all of these things at once.

We went with that and the mushrooms, and it was all very delicious.  The thing with Ethiopian food to me is, I can't have that much.  But that results in an unhappy tummy, who wants more food.  Well that's what happened after finishing our meal, we were still hungry.  We ordered two entrees, normally we would be full so we came to the conclusion that portions were on the smaller side and for each entree to be about $10+ for a cafe this is on the pricier side.  Though what makes it unique is obviously that it serves Ethiopian food, fast but in no way does it compromise quality.
author: Leslie L.

description: Tried for thefirst time ethiopian food and I must say it was excellent. Big and tasty portion of meat with salad which blends in perfectly into the meal.
author: Marko Ć.

description: Still loving the Moya over in their new space - so glad they were able to bounce back from the fire. Same great people, same bangin' food. They close a little early, so make it a lunch/early dinner thing.
author: Megan W.

description: I was not very happy with this place.  There are better Ethiopian places in the city.  The food was pretty oily (noticeably) and the lentils were not cooked entirely.  Better place to go: New Eritrea
author: Sonam J.

description:
Fresh and tasty with a spicy kick in the pants!

Food = 4.0: I met my cousin for lunch at Moya and we shared the spicy red lentils and the spicy chicken (doro tibs).  Each came with a small salad and two small relishes.  We also got rice and injera bread.  The lentils and chicken were super flavorful and they had nice heat.  Portions were pretty fair.  Next time, I will order the vegetarian sampler, which looked enormous!

Service = 3.5:  You order at the counter and they bring the plates to you.  The ladies working the place were very nice.  A half star bump for being able to pay with Square.

Atmosphere = 4.0:  This space is way better than their previous space at 6th and Folsom.  Their first location was consumed by fire but as they say, "Everything happens for a reason."  Thus, this new, clean and better location on 9th in the SoMa!
author: Eddie L.

description:
Went here to have a 10 person team meeting in a place that was quiet and well lit that served dinner.  This place fit our needs perfectly.  The family style vegetarian platters with sides of chicken or beef [the beef with sauteed onion was by far the best meat dish we tried].  The owner is warm and welcoming.  You feel like you're in her home.

We are having monthly meetings at this spot.  Only $160 for the group!  Great fun.
author: Jonathan B.

description: A social dining place to share ordered the veggie sampler with siga tibs. It was really delicious, the beef was done just right. A causal dinning place with fantastic food. Recommended.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
Why aren't there more people in this place? It has a great homey feel, prices are good (maybe a little steep if you're eating only meat dishes), and the food is solid. My friend and I split a veggie lunch special and the lamb tibs which were delicious. I understand that if you compare the food to all the Ethiopian places in the East Bay maybe Moya doesn't stand out. But it exists, and it's here in SoMa, and I appreciate that!

I just got back from eating lunch here and we were only one of two parties in the whole restaurant at 12:30PM. I think this place is good enough to deserve a bigger lunch crowd than they are getting. So, if you're hungry reading this right now, trying to figure out where to get your lunch in SoMa, please give Moya a chance!
author: Josh K.

description:
Beware - these people are rip-off merchants. I always give places a second chance, but I have been burned here twice and am now warning you.
We ordered two samplers which were $9.95 on the menu. When it was rung up on the cash register, it came to $30. After questioning this, I was left standing for 15 minutes while the server was on the phone. I was then told the price was wrong and it is $12.95. No problem - just refund me the difference for the advertised price seeing as they made the mistake of handing me a menu which clearly outlined the prices. This was refused. After the food being at our table, I thought to myself; forget about it and let it go. The crazy thing is this happened the first time I went here, but thought nothing of it as I was in a rush at the time.
After we ran out of bread, I asked if we could have some more seeing as you need it to eat as Ethiopian food is eaten without cutlery. I was told that would be $2 more. Anyone with any business savvy at all would realize that this is just plain rude after scamming me out of extra which was advertised falsely. 
My wife (who is an attorney and deals with these matters) approached the manager who told us we were wrong and we needed to leave. She threw $20 on our table (even though we paid $30) and pushed us out the door.
This is hands down the rudest, most passive aggressive behavior I have encountered in the city and warn you to STEER CLEAR OF THIS PLACE AT ALL COSTS. They are thieves. 
Shame, because I really like Ethiopian food. Go elsewhere.
author: Luke C.

description:
So delicious, we are delighted that Moya moved to the 'hood, despite the unfortunate circumstances. Nothing beats smelling the savory Ethiopian spices over the (ahem) street 'fragrance' now only donning the corner of 9th & Minna Sundays. 

And how blown away were we that the food is downright excellent? That the flavors are scrumptious? That the staff is so lovely, one wants to visit them again and again? Damn! did we get lucky!

I seriously could go on & on, but go there yourself... you'll agree.
author: Alexis R.

description:
Great Ethiopian food near civic center / SOMA and conveniently close to bart.

I stopped in for lunch recently and ordered the veggie combo lunch plate. Service was quick and the food was delicious. Order at the counter, grab your own napkin and water and they bring your plate out to you in a few minutes. You can also grab yourself a fork if you prefer not to eat with your fingers but are too embarrassed to ask for one. :-)

It's too bad I don't work in that part of the city anymore or I'd be there all the time.
author: Rob B.

description:
Best Ethiopian I've found in SF. Moya wins for flavor, 100% teff injera, and portion size. Only Sheba has marginally better texture.

Veggie combo is always awesome, and the shuro is phenomenal. Friendly family runs the place -- mother cooking and daughters serving. Street parking has always been easy to find too.

Absolute pleasure to eat here, which I do 2-3 times a week.
author: Todd I.

description:
More Moya.

Take a traditional Ethiopian platter.

Swap the injera house baked sandwich bread.

Inside put a generous portion of chicken with just the right amount of kick.

Prepare smooth house drip coffee for those of us who need a kick.

Together they gave me delicious reason to come back for a second visit.
author: Jason B.

description: Came for a quick lunch. Love Ethiopian food. Pleased they offer a vegan lunch sampler with four dishes, with side salad, and a brown rice option instead of traditional injera bread, so gluten-avoiders can be very happy here.
author: Scott S.

description: Got the veggie platter to go today.  They were fast and food was super fresh and delicious.  Service was perfect. Portion was very generous, I shared it with several work mates and everyone loved it.  I will definitely be back.
author: stephanie s.

description:
I ate here on my day off one time.

I got this crazy Ethiopian tar tar dish, that was super spicy (I can take spicy but this was kinda too much). The sides were kinda cool, and it was definitely an experience. The only bad part is that I got food poisoning from the raw meat, so did my friend who got something else entirely different. 

Best dish: The sides
Food: 2/5 stars
Ambiance: Like a cafe
Price: 10/person 
Service: The cashier was sweet
author: Kevi L.

description:
Great food. It took a long time though.

We ordered the vegetarian sampler entree, which took 45 mintes. I'm pretty sure everything was pre-cooked, so I'm not sure why it took so long. (It wasn't even crowded.)

But yeah, the food was great. I recommend Moya, but not if you're in a rush.
author: Wes F.

description:
My first Ethiopian food experience.  Nice lady at the counter.  I had a spicy beef dish recommended by her.  It was really good and I enjoyed it a lot with the rice.  I thought the side dishes didn't really compliment.

I work next door, so will definitely have Moya on my choices.
author: Pam S.

description: Huge fan - this place is a gem in a somewhat cutty part of town. Food comes out quickly, they offer online ordering, I can't stop eating there. Try the veggie sampler and you can't go wrong.
author: Fallon M.

description: Came here for lunch a couple days ago with some co-workers. I had high hopes with the significant vegetarian options but out of the three of us, no one liked what they got. Everything was bland yet odd tasting at the same time, if that makes sense. I got the chickpea stew boasting of 15 spices, which was basically 11 bucks for a small dollop of creamy peanut butter mixed with tomato sauce on top of a ton of rice. All the water glasses looked dirty and everything was overpriced. Nothing awful but definitely wouldn't go back.
author: Gina L.

description: I've always been curious about Ethiopian food, but never had the opportunity until now. Glad to say my introduction was a great one. The waitress (I think her name was Mellay) was very polite, and helpful, very pretty as well. She really made the experience worth while. I wasn't sure about what to order, so I let her know that I didn't really fancy spicy food, and asked her for her recommendation and she said she would take care of me, and she did. She brought me a veggie sampler and chicken drumsticks with rice. I really underestimated this food because I didn't really expect it to taste as good as it did. I will definitely be returning to this restaurant in the near future. Great food along with great service!
author: Branden S.

description:
I love Ethiopian food and was sorely disappointed by this place. There are so many great Ethiopian places in the bay area.
1. They charge for the injera. They give you a tiny basket and then you have to go buy more when you use up your first basket.
2. The injera was cold, kind of hard and definitely not fresh
3. The food was just meh - normally Ethiopian is one of my favorites
4. The lady handed me the bathroom key chain and then proceeded to give people their food and take orders without washing her hands! After returning the key, I lost my appetite for eating food with my hands which had held the bathroom key.
author: Mickie D.

description: I had heard some great things about this place but I was disappointed. I lived around Berkeley a lot and got to try lots of good Ethiopian food and this did not live up to those standards. We ordered the vegetarian platter and the mushroom tibs. The vegetarian platter was pretty bland and tasteless - I think my favorite entree on that was the spicy red lentils. The mushroom tibs were wayy too spicy; it practically tasted like they accidentally dumped a bunch of chili powder on it. Wasn't the best and wasn't the worst, but I'm not sure if I'd go back.
author: Malika R.

description: The hands down best Ethiopian Food I've ever had.  There are other spots in the Bay Area but Moya keeps me coming back.  The vegetarian options are flavorful and the spices are so unique.  I always bring my friends here when I want to impress them.
author: Jay B.

description: Quite possibly some of the nicest people in the neighborhood, I love the people of Moya. The veggie sampler is my favorite from the menu and the sandwiches are also a great choice. This is a great lunch for sharing.
author: Dana O.

description: 2nd visit is more tasty than the first, less salty, and the staff is very accommodating.  We ordered the veggie platter, the KITFO- steak tartare with nice and fluffy brown rice and mushroom platter served family style (if asked) for lunch .  This place is an oasis from the hustle and bustle.
author: Helen L.

description: Fantastic food - modest surrounds.  Would have given it five stars but they had run out of various options by 6 pm - I guess that's a great recommendation for their food!
author: Zoe B.

description:
We started with the azifa appetizer (lentil w/ red onions, jalapeño, garlic, lemon, olive oil, and served w/ kita (homemade Ethiopian bread) or injera). Now that I think about it, I don't think we were offered a choice between kita and injera, but I think we got kita since it was different from the injera we had later in the meal. This appetizer was wonderful, although I didn't really think there was a large enough portion to split among five people.

We had the shuro, ye doro wat, kik alitcha, gomen, ayb (cheese), and ye bere tibs. I liked the vegetarian dishes a lot - as usual, Ethiopian is the only way I like collard greens. The ye doro wat was also phenomenal - their bere bere sauce is my personal favorite. I think I would skip the beef next time, and I didn't find the shuro to be as amazing as everyone else does - it reminded me of the sauce from chicken tikka masala - not bad, just not interesting. It seemed like there was a lot of salad around too, which was just ok.

Service was quite good, and a fair amount of that consisted of continual injera refills (greatly appreciated). I found the atmosphere to be rather sterile (is that why people keep calling it "clean"?), although it was filling up by 8:00 or so on a Tuesday evening.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I love coming here. The restaurant is literally right next door to my office, which is quite dangerous considering you only need to be within a 500 ft. radius of the place in order to get a tantalizing whiff of the delicious spices at play in all their dishes. Plus the staff is super friendly and helpful when an indecisive girl like me leaves the decision-making up to them ;)

You can't go wrong with the veggie sampler, but when I'm on a budget I really like getting the red lentil rolled into the injera bread, and cut into cocktail roll pieces. $5+tax. Not too shabby, especially for something so tasty! I can only ever get through 3/4 of it, anyway. Mmmm...I think I'll get some tomorrow..
author: Angelica D.

description:
Great chicken dol wat, Vegetarian sampler (especially the red lentils and collard greens), and Teff-only Injera!
Super friendly staff of Ethiopian women in a sparsely decorated but cozy and clean restaurant.  Would definitely come here again and hope it makes it for the long term.  Really enjoyed the berbere spice and balance of flavors.
author: Ya-Bing C.

description:
I wanted to check this place out because their reviews were good so I went with my boyfriend during my lunch break. My first time trying Ethiopian food and I am in love now. The ambience fits perfectly with its location (downtown S.F. industrial). The staff is very friendly and the place is surprisingly very spacious. We came in just before the lunch rush hour so we got our food in a timely manner. 

I had the Ingudai Doro Tibs platter extra spicy and it was amazing. The injera (ethiopian bread) has a very interesting texture almost spongy but I quite enjoyed it. I do regret not ordering the veggie sampler that everyone talks about. 

Their lunch menu is one page which is very fitting because I hate restaurants with menus the size of a short novel. I will definitely be coming back to this place so I can try some more of their items.

*like any where else in the city parking is hard to find; however, we got lucky and snagged a parking spot a few feet away from the restaurant.
author: Kirita S.

description:
Gluten free injeria! I am so glad Moya is back. I liked their first location on Folsom better and hope that one day they return to more of a dining experience rather than the cafe venue that have now BUT I am just happy to have them back.

I love their Ethiopian food! They make great vegetarian options which taste fresh. They have wonderful gluten free and meat options for my friends.  The only way it can get better is to improve the environment.
author: max k.

description:
Our family tried Moya for the first time this weekend and the kids loved the DORA TIBS and eating with their hands.  The staff was family friendly and immediately pushed two tables together to accommodate us.  The food was good and served QUICKLY.  The veggie sampler, an order of the Dora Tibs, and an extra order of Injera bread was the ample for 2 adults and 2 kids.

Really, an Ethiopian restaurant should have a sink outside of the bathroom area so patrons can quickly and easily wash their hands before the meal.  Dealing with the bathroom key (understood as it is SOMA) and only one bathroom is not very efficient.
author: Rudy R.

description:
THE BEST ETHIOPIAN PLACE IN THE CITY!!!!

NO QUESTION, THE PLACE TO GO.

For the first time in my LIFE I had real all-teff injera.  I couldn't even get this stuff in the middle east an hours flight from Addis Abba.  This is an acquired taste so I don't recommend it unless you are really into injera, but everything here is tasty and flavorful.  

Finally an Ethiopian place that has a cool modern interior and fast service.  They are also generous with the proportions.

IS
author: M S.

description:
Amazing food. Especially for vegetarians.
Quick service.
Variety of exotic flavors
I was able to get a nutritious dish which had 4 meals into one
author: casti c.

description: The doro tibs and siga tibs is out of this world good here!  They deserve each of those stars for so many reason outside of their delicious food!  The service and awesome location are two of those reasons.  Mix it with perfect service, kind staff, and my wife also loves it as the other three.
author: Rachelle G.

description:
Damn good food! 
Its pretty greasy, but its different. 
You just have to try it for yourself.
author: Lauren K.

description: The food is good! Hearty, filling, and enough for two meals. I ordered their special for the day and for lunch it can be a bit pricey, but if you want to splurge then this is a great spot. I'm not found of the bread, but the salad was great.
author: Theresa D.

description:
First, they need to take a new photo and update their Yelp listing;  the current photo is of their previous restaurant location.  Their new spot is brand new and simplistic.

Their food has been wonderful and has been my choice twice this week along with many people from our office just a couple yards away.

My only recommendation thus far is that because you eat w/ your fingers I feel they should have MUCH better napkins and/or wet wipes to use.  But hey, they have only been open 3 days, so I'll cut some slack and see how everything works out in a couple months.

KEEP UP THE GREAT WORK!!!
author: Michael S.

description:
Hooooray! Great new place to eat at in SOMA. 

Wonderful place to eat lunch at during the week. The staff is warm and friendly. The service is quick. The place is clean unlike the sidewalk directly outside the door.

My recs: 
Gursha - injera with red lentils ($6 for a box of rolls; great for a small lunch kind of day), the veggie 

Mushroom- Chicken Tibs - a very savory stew with mushroom and chicken. It's delicious and very filling.

Veggie sampler

Really love this place and couldn't be happier that they are on 9th!!
author: liz c.

description: Great food and great service. Always lovely to stop by and have a dinner. Love the vegan option!
author: Larry L.

description: I loved the chicken dishes, liked vegetarian dishes, simple and tasty. Not expensive either. Recommended for a quick lunch/dinner
author: Balu V.

description: Good spot for lunch in a neighborhood with - in my opinion - not a lot of options.
author: Lorin L.

description:
HURRAY FOR ALL! GOODNESS PREVAILS! WHEN YOU PLAY THE GAME OF THRONES, YOU WIN OR YOU DIE!

And Moya wins!

They are now re-opened again after the horrific experience they went through after last year's SRO fire on 6th & Folsom! (Read all about it here: http://www.eatmoya.com/about-moya/ )

I'm so excited!!!!
author: Joshua L.

description: This is a review for delivery. I ordered through eat 24, and my order arrived in twenty minutes. A miracle! I got tofu dibs and shuro. Both were fresh, hot, fantastic. The lady who delivered was super sweet, too. A new favorite, for sure.
author: beesknee s.

description: Very delicious, though less spicy than I was expecting (from Ethiopian food I've eaten in NYC).  The vegetarian sampler entree was varied and plentiful - which had I known, I would have ordered the red lentil appetizer (also plentiful, and delicious).  The decor is minimal but my food was cooked and served quickly.
author: Tom M.

description:
Oh Moya, how I love thee.  When life feels bland and cold, theres nothing more satisfying than Moya's deliciously authentic, uber-flavorful dishes.  Ive had almost every type of dish so far (working my way through the different meats of each type), and all have been a tasty delight!  The best way to do Moya is to go with 4 people.   That was you can get the Veggie Platter, which is more than enough to feed 2 hungry boys, and then you can order another dish or two. Dont be afraid to try the Kitfo, which should be ordered spicy and as they intend...rare.  One you get over the rawness, your taste buds will go wild. I always order a side of their housemade cottage cheese to tame the spices a bit.  I must also add that I love to eat with my hands.

I cant wait until they open again, after recovering from a fire set off at the hotel next door by some jagoff that cooked with his bbq inside!  Once theyre ready, Ill be charging the doors!
author: Mike H.

description: Simply spectacular. The food is great and the portions are just right.. I will be coming here again and again. Service also really good.. Cafe vibe. Btw the vegetable platter is amazing.
author: Robert S.

description: Hmmm.... I'm torn. The food wasn't bad but the aftermath was awful. My roommate and I ate here and we both had the spicy beef which came back with a vengeance. We both had food poisoning and it was not fun. I can't bring myself to give t a second chance so good luck to you guys.
author: William L.

description:
Between two, we ordered the Vegetarian Combo, which is clearly marked to serve two. Since it was our first time at Moya, we decided to order an additional meat dish [Bozena Shuro] to share. It was a good thing that the two of us hadn't eaten much since brunch and were actually quite hungry because that was a lot of food! We went through an additional serving of injera to scrap up the last goops of deliciousness before we admitted defeat. Next time [and there will definitely be a next time], we'll just order the combo for two. 

Eating with your hands can be a lot of fun, but be sure to wash them before you begin! I've been to a handful of Ethiopian/Eritrean places, and Moya has to be one of my favorites. 

The only downside of the place is their automatic door. It takes a few seconds to shut, and if you're at one of the tables by the door, you have to put on your jacket to stay warm.
author: Tinna H.

description:
4th week of Lent, and I've just about exhausted my catalog of vegan dishes to cook at home. I am a sad, sad kitten. Tired of cooking, and restaurants are uninspiring. 

But, Praise Moya!!
I am enamored with your Injera! I am mystified by your Misir Wot! I am grateful for your greens! Your Kik Alitcha kicks ass!

I found you today, and may you never leave me! Meat or no meat, you are a godsend!

Lent certified, Carnley approved. VEGAN FRIENDLY!
author: Carnley P.

description: A small place with a seating seating capacity of 20 may be.. Not so elegant and fancy.. Mostly quiet.. But the food is to die for.. They are best at what they are expected to do.. That's serving great food.. Good option for vegetarians.. Spicy and great portions.. Have an option to order food family style, which works out great.. Loved the vegetarian injera, Doro tibs and misir wot!
author: Madhuri S.

description:
I've only been to a handful of Ethiopian restaurants (about 8 restaurants in 4 different cities) but Moya was easily the best. The kitfo was amazing, and they have mushrooms here, which have been a little hard for me to find. The portions were ridiculous -- we spent about $20 per person and didn't even come close to finishing what we ordered.

My only complaints are that they don't serve beer or honey wine, and that the mushrooms which we ordered medium were not even the least bit spicy. Considering that there was a person at my table who seemed hesitant about the spiciness, that may have been our server acting a little too cautious.

And speaking of our server, she was fantastic. I've learned not to judge an Ethiopian restaurant by the attentiveness of their waitstaff, but our server kept our water refilled and brought us extra napkins and injera without us having to ask. It was perfect.

If they start serving alcohol I will not hesitate to bump my review up to 5 stars. Regardless, I will be back as soon as possible.

Please go here and keep it hopping! This is exactly the kind of restaurant that deserves to thrive in San Francisco.
author: J W.

description: Having doubts about trying Ethiopian cuisine?  Dont, and just go! You will be quite happy.  Vegetarian friendly! We had the mixed plate, and was more than enough for two.  Their flat bread was delicious, potato, greens all wonderful.  It is counter service, so great for a sit down or order grab and go.
author: Michael C.

description:
This was for a lunch catering order:

I normally get my Ethiopian food in San Jose at Walia Ethiopian cuisine, but I wanted to cater Ethiopian food for my work friends!  

Most of the Ethiopian restaurants in SF only open after 5 PM, so Moya happened to be my best (and only) choice - ALSO, they were the most tech-savvy with online ordering options too! :)  That being said - the food was delicious, and a total hit with people who'd had Ethiopian before and first-timers! 

Part of the 5 stars is for Mellay.  She called me to consult on the amount, actually recommended I order less (who does that in the restaurant biz?!), delivered for free and even comped some doro wat! (which I LOVE)

This is as good as it gets.
author: tiffany t.

description: Went here while I was briefly staying in SF. It was my first Ethiopian experience so I can't accurately rate the cuisine, it was, however very delicious. I got the spicy beef tips and it was delicious. The bread is made in house daily and was super delicious. I'd come back if I lived nearby. It was $15 for the meal so a little more than I'd like considering that was sans drink. Wasn't super crowded and the girl working was very helpful while ordering since I mentioned it was my first Ethiopian experience.
author: Lauren M.

description:
The chicken Doro sandwich was spicy and DEEELISH, chock full of onion & green pepper on a nice soft baguette.  Green lentil salad was excellent as well!
Iced tea had a lovely light spice to it too.

A welcome addition to the neighborhood, will definitely be coming back for work-week lunches!
author: Jeffery T.

description: I've never had Ethiopian food before, so granted, I don't have anything to compare it to.  This place is very casual but a little pricey since it's in Soma.  The service wasn't very friendly, which is why I didn't give it the last star.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood!  I was quite excited to find out you were reopening so close by, it was well worth the wait.

The veggie sampler and injera were great;  Can't wait to try more items.  Hopefully you'll be able to serve honey wine again.
author: Tony D.

description:
Went here for lunch with 3 others. They hadn't had Ethiopian food before. I had eaten it a few times and wasn't taken seriously when I said you eat it with your hands.

Well, um: ya do. You tear off a piece of injera (a bread with a very sponge-like consistency), wrap it around some food, and chow away.

We ordered a variety of items consisting of the tofu tibs, ye doro tibs (chicken), vegetarian combo, and one of the beef items (sorry, the name escapes me).

Even though the place was almost empty when we were there, it took about 15 minutes to get the food prepared. When it arrived, it was served on a single, giant platter. It took up almost the entire table. In addition to what we had ordered, they threw on a couple of samples other menu items. The place was clearly very new, so the staff probably hasn't had time to work out the kinks of running the place yet.

Portion size: excellent. The four of us left feeling stuffed. And this is a fairly active group of people, accustomed to burning a lot of calories.

Service: It took it awhile, but the waitress was very friendly and quite knowledgeable about the details of menu items and of Ethiopian cuisine in general. So, "very good."

Value: Considering the quantity of food, it's very good.

Drawbacks: 

1) the prices were a bit high for lunch (average entree was about $13). Since they seem to want to attract a noontime crowd, they need to have prices that are appealing. Note: their website indicates that they have "lunch specials" now, so perhaps that's since been remedied.

2) Because you eat this food with your hands, they need to provide tableside hand-cleaning both BEFORE and AFTER you eat. Perhaps some warm, wet towels or something. And yes, I know: there is a restroom in the back, but if the place gets busy, there's going to be a crowd waiting for it. Also, public restrooms can get really icky.

3.4 stars.
author: Tim B.

description: Food is disappointing - used to be good, I loved the veggie platter which used to be served on a bed of injera, along with injera served on the side to dip the food in and the price was 9.95. Fast forward to now, 2018, price is now $12.95, and they no longer serve the injera underneath the plate of food- which is the tradition. And, i requested injera gluten free but they served it with gluten and told me they were out of the gluten free that day, but neglected to tell me prior to ordering. Employees seem disengaged and the place has gotten more pricey but gone down hill. They  are obsessed apparently with cutting corners and at the same time still raising the price. Would not recommend, too many really good Ethiopian places in this town.
author: Kay C.

description: All I have to say is their Kitfo, raw(beef), is the best I've ever had! Their fresh cheese had a really good taste to it, came with some salad and light dressing. All was plated very nicely and tasted delicious! I've had Kitfo at many different restaurants and for the price and quality, you can't go wrong at Moya!
author: Matthew R.

description: I got food poisoning my first and only time here. Three of us shared the vegetarian sampler and the recommended chicken dish. All three of us were sick the next day. Super painful. Food was good but nothing makes up for a day lost.
author: Cassandra R.

description: Good place for lunch, mild to hot spices.  Chicken was great.  Bread is like crepes.  Service friendly but a bit slow.
author: Mike M.

description:
Get the vegetable combination plus a choice of meat, easy to share between two and leave satisfied!

The Kitfo was pretty good. But my favorite is the vegetable combination.

Unfortunately no beer or wine served here.
author: Jenna P.

description:
Fast, friendly, large portions, well spiced, and pleasing to all vegetarians/vegans, meat eaters and gluten free diets. My only complaint is that it's a little too oily.

They have counter service, which keeps things affordable at lunch time. The menu is on the small side but it works because it seems more like a lunch spot. It's quite hard to find good lunch in the Civic Center aread. Moya has been added to my repertoire, which includes Ananda Fuara (a fantastic option).

The lunch crowd seems like mostly 30 year old male techies. But, so does San Francisco these days.
author: Sophia L.

description:
First time experiencing Ethiopian cuisine.  Waitress was really friendly and made some good suggestions in terms of what us first timers should try.  Also, she gave us a couple samplings of the vegetarian dishes since we ordered only meats which prompted us to order the red lentils next time we come back.

We ordered the Kitfo (spicy rare beef with cottage cheese) and Ye Doro Tibs (lamb with clarified butter in spices).  Both dishes had lots of delicious flavor, especially combined with the injera bread served.  We loved the lamb dish the most, so much complex spices and flavor and the lamb was cooked so tender that it broke apart once we try to scoop it up with the injera bread.

We will be back for sure.
author: Yun W.

description:
Some of the best food in the city!  The cafe is casual and food is tasty and healthfully balanced.  BONUS:  The injera is 100% teff, so great for wheat-free eating.   Moya is owner operated, the women are fantastic and the food is lovingly prepard and served with pride.  This restaurant is one of our GO TO spots for a casual dinner out or take-out.  

Best kept left-overs secret:  fry up that injera  is a spec of olive oil and eat it with eggs for breakfast.  Puts soughdough bread to shame!
author: Beth B.

description:
Delicious. Flavorful. Cheap. Don't consider anywhere else for Ethiopian!

If it's your first time going, I'd go for the vegetarian combo for two ($15) so you can try everything. I really liked the chickpeas and the collard greens but really, everything was great.

My only complaint is the environment wasn't extremely comfortable. It was clean but extremely simple and cafe-style tables. It was fine but not extremely homey. That being said, the service was great and unless you're really trying to impress someone with the decor of the restaurant, I'd recommend this for any occasion.
author: Wen-fai F.

description: Gonna give these guys another chance, but my vote so far is no. The garlic flavor in some of the dishes was strange - strong and pungent - almost as if it came from a jar. It pretty much ruined every dish it was in. The second chance is to see if the garlic just happened to be from a bad batch or something.  Otherwise, I'm out - way out.
author: Bib G.

description:
This was my first time eating Ethiopian and Moya popped my cherry gently. 

Like a true virgin I wasn't really adventurous and started with the gursha, which was my favorite dish.  We picked 2 entrees and the ye doro wot was tender and the ye beg tibs was sweet. I asked for spicy ye beg tibs but I didn't find it spicy at all. Maybe I should have asked for super spicy.
 
If you are value conscious the portions are huge and on top of that the injera which is given with every order is very filling. 

Service was friendly and efficient.  Our server sensed we were inexperienced and had plenty of patience with us.

The one drawback is the lack of alcohol and dessert. I really could have used a nice red for my lamb.
author: Roger H.

description: I tried this place for the first time last night and ordered the veggie combo. Their food was ok. The injera was too thick for me. Was more like a pancake & the food didn't have much flavor. But it beats Burger King or any other fast food.
author: Brooke B.

description: Went to dinner here the other night on a recommendation from a Lyft driver. The veggie sampler was delicious.
author: Valerie D.

description: Good food and prompt service. A group of 5 of us went here before headed to a play. Neighborhood is kind of sketchy, but food was fantastic!
author: Perklunk L.

description: There are times when you want a taste of authentic Ethiopian cuisine however it lacked the hospitality warmth and taste.  It was disappointing to say the least. It was bland.  It is just a fast food take out , no thought of taste  restaurant.
author: J. D.

description:
Yay, I was very excited to find out that they reopened but meh....ok, so a friend grabbed the chicken tibse to go for me last week. I opened the box drooling to find the chicken immersed in oil and not the good kind( no enjera in the bottom of the tibse? where they do that at?). It was bland and greasy. The salad was wilted and tasted funny. To top it off the enjera came on the side, and only two stale pieces. 

I'll keep going to Sheba till they get their acts together. 

Moya, you got to do better because you know better.
author: Sofie Z.

description: Will be back here again, love the food and service and ppl.
author: Johnson H.

description:
So glad to finally have an authentic, mom and pop type Ethiopian place in the work hood.

The food is amazing, and yes the rapport with customers is great too- the waitress told us that every dish is cooked by her mom and aunt with love. Half way through the meal both the mom and aunt came to check on us and talk about the real deal injera made only with Teff, the staple grain of Ethiopia (and also gluten free for those who care).

I had the Ye Doro Wot, chicken marinated in lemon juice, then sautéed in a rich sauce made with garlic, onion, fresh ginger, and Berbere (special house blend of red chili peppers and other traditional spices) sauce, and kibe (clarified butter with spices) and cooked slowly until tender. Served with a hard boiled egg.

Their menu doesn't lie, the meat was fall off the bone tender, and sooooo good.
author: megan k.

description:
I am still getting my Ethiopian-food legs, so to speak, and I learned a lot from my dinner at Moya. 

As much as I loved it, after we ate at New Eritrea, I was going to give myself a long break from Ethiopean food. It just didn't seem right to eat it without having the full experience -- by which I mean the injera -- and nobody in San Francisco was making injera with 100% teff. But then Moya came along. 

Times are hard in Africa, especially hard right now, and there is a severe teff shortage. Teff is an impressively tiny grain grown in Africa that is dark brown in color, sour-flavored, a bit gummy when cooked, and is the basis for traditional injera. You can still buy teff in America -- at a price. Most restaurants are keeping their costs down by cutting their teff with wheat, which is great for the budget but frustrating for folks with gluten allergies. Moya, instead, makes two kinds of injera -- one with wheat, and one without. They charge a little more for the teff-only version, which is brilliant. I wish other Ethiopean places would do this. 

So, I decided to reverse my moratorium on Ethiopean food and give Moya a try. My date and I visited on a Friday evening; the restaurant had a few diners but wasn't packed. The decor is more cafe than African, though it is clean and feels friendly. We were encouraged to sit anywhere, and urged to try the ye beg wot, a tender lamb dish that had just come out of the pot and was getting rave reviews from other diners. I ordered it, while my date braved the ultra-rare kitfo. I also explained that I am allergic to gluten, and ordered the teff-only injera for my meal. 

My date ordered the azifa, and I had a taste of the zesty lentils before he began spooning them onto pieces of flatbread (wheat-based, so I couldn't have it). His kitfo came out soon after, along with a plate with a couple of extra rolls of injera. The woman who brought the food set the injera down next to me, so I assumed it was mine. Excited to try it, I took a bite. 

A few minutes later, my food came out -- and I noticed the injera on my plate was much darker than the stuff I'd just eaten. It tasted different, too; more like pure teff. Uh oh. I talked with the woman who'd served our food, and she confirmed that the injera I'd tried earlier had wheat in it. She claimed she told us that it was my date's, not mine, but admitted it was confusing that she had set it in front of me. They agreed to knock the cost of my injera off the order, and I wondered if that would make up for the allergic reaction I might have later. 

Nevertheless, the lamb was amazing. The meat was tender and rich, complemented by the light sourness of the injera. The sauce was buttery and spicy, also a perfect foil for the bread. I would have loved more salad, and was surprised by how quickly I was filled by the meal. I had enough to take home and enjoy for lunch the next day. My date liked his kitfo even more than my lamb. 

I didn't wind up having a truly bad reaction to the bite of wheat I got, though I did feel crummy for a couple of days after. Plus, I learned how to tell the difference between the wheat-laced injera and the stuff that's safe for me to eat, so I would feel comfortable going back. 

I'm docking one star for the allergy-related confusion, and reluctantly docking one more because I wish they had a wine selection to go with the food -- Ethiopean honey wine, at the very least.
author: Beth W.

description:
The sight of stony grey, spongy, aerated, injera bread rolled on a plate is motivation to plot a course on GOOGLE maps and head outside.  If it's a few blocks away, I'll just do a YELPY and see what the vibe is....I know, not exactly road less traveled, throw caution to the wind, stuff that adventures are made of but..when I am salivating over menus on the web and my tummy needs filling...I don't like to take too many risks.  I know, got to live on the 'food' edge more.

VEGANSAURUS rated MOYA as ^swear word^ delicious, 'Moya rules' .  Enough said.  My coat was flying behind me as I attempted to get dressed and walk down the street at the same time.  Skill.

I walked down Folsom to 7th, past some rather 'interesting' bars.  I'd railroaded my foodie pal into eating an early dinner (for Glen it was a late lunch/early dinner...a linner?  Well..we accepted the word brunch didn't we?!)  The restaurant only had one couple tucking in when we arrived.  More arrived whilst we scoffed.

We ordered the vegetarian combo (yes, 'tis vegan), a buffet/taster plate.  Five dishes  spooned on Teff - a nutritious Ethiopian grain..Wiki tells it. gluten-free, injera bread.  The salad was simply chopped toms and lettuce but dusted with white pepper - usually pet hate of mine, but..it worked, I was converted; a stew of carrots kale; slow cooked collard greens; yellow split peas in garlic & spices and split red lentils in Berbere sauce.  I also called ahead (obsessive planning!..but they ask for 30mins notice) to get them whipping up some Shuro (ground garbanzos cooked in garlic & Berbere sauce).  Vegansaurus said to order it and slather it on everything as it was like liquid butter... 

The injera was good..perfect in fact.  A texture like nothing else.  The palate of dishes in the veggie combo?  I enjoyed the salad..actually I enjoyed EVERYTHING.  The red split lentils were worthy of a trumpeted fanfare and mini indoor sparklers..yey!  The other dishes were good but my socks were not blown off, tic-a-tape did not rain from the sky and I did not  take to the floor to perform three somersaults, air straddle splits and a triple salto in celebration.  Hmm, I'd go again.. but I'd gorge (and you do gorge..they are GENEROUS portions) on the spicy misir and an injera or two.  I'd save my dosh for spending on a sweet vegan goodie from Rainbow Grocery on the way home and give the Shuro a miss too ..it didn't rock my boat..more of a gentle nudge from the wake of a passing ship., ok, ok, you knew what I meant.


Plus points; the food was brought out in minutes, the cooks/server seemed (quietly) proud of their food.
Minus; they currently only take cash BUT they do have an ATM
author: Leigh With A Veganobsession X.

description: My first experience at Moya was a revelation - I had heard many things about ethiopian food, but I had never tried it before I came to Moya. I can't speak to its authenticity, but having been there multiple times, I can say that they serve consistently amazing food.
author: Ivan M.

description:
We live in the neighborhood and are wondering why we have not been here since. It was my first time eating Ethiopian food and I must say everything was excellent. I love the fact the place is a family business. I had the Kifto dulte , vegetarian combination and ye doro wot. Everything tasted fantastic. There was enough food for 2 more people. Our waitress even gave us a few items to try for free. 
Looking forward to going back again.
author: Robert O.

description:
Overall, it was a good experience. I ordered the veggie sampler lunch and the portion of lentils, potatoes and salad was really huge. The salad has more of a 'california' twist to it than I would have preferred and they had a side dish that resembled more of a Mexican salsa fresca than anything Ethiopian so I have to ding them a bit for true authenticity. 
I had to round up to four stars but I would've really given this place a 3.5. Having just returned from a trip to Ethiopia, I was excited when a friend asked me to do lunch at a local Ethiopian cafe. I saw on their website that they offer macchiato, which got me really excited. 
Unfortunately, their machine was broken and the only alternative was just a drip coffee they had made. Bummer. 
Also, the portion of injera that goes along with lunch was a little too small and an extra order costs $2 bucks. As a redeeming factor, however, the staff was extremely friendly (I expect no less from Ethiopians!) and she ended up giving it to us for free.
Amasegenalu!! 

PS: if anyone out there who is a big fan of Ethiopian food has managed to find fruit "spreece" or salad "atakelt", please let me know!! I miss them so much!!
author: Drea C.

description:
Very very good.  Much better than the stuff we get at restaurants in boston.     As good as the what we've had in Ethiopia.  The chef was very friendly.  It's exactly what we wanted after a long flight.

I only wish they made Ethiopian coffee.
author: Brett J.

description: Good ethiopian, but the portions for the price is a bit pricey but what I would expect from ethiopian food in the city. Though tasty, I will still be going to the all you can eat ethiopian buffet on ashby and telegraph in berkeley. If you go there, make sure not to eat the injera bread first it will expand in your stomach and you will barely be able to finish your first plate. They also include the mushroom and berbere sauce entree in the buffet which is usually left out of veggie combos at other ethiopian restaurants.
author: Onika C.

description: Most wonderful flavors! I could eat the chicken dish (choro) every day!
author: Fernanda M.

description:
I have to up the rating.. unlimited injera!
Get the Shuro, the menu says it will take 30 minutes but I don't think it felt that long, and it was worth the wait.
author: Kaushal P.

description:
The most striking thing about Moya compared to other Ethiopian restaurants is that it was very clean. Most other Ethiopian places that I've been to are very delicious but not exactly a neat freak's paradise. Moya is both clean and delicious.

We have been here twice, and both times we ordered a vegetarian combo and Ye Doro Tibs with chicken - shared, of course. Both were very good. I highly recommend getting an order of the vegetarian combo because it gives you a chance to sample many different dishes.

Another positive differentiator of Moya over other Ethiopian places is their attentive service, especially when bringing over fresh injera, which we always seem to run out of several times. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Adam B.

description: Went here last Friday for dinner and it was DELISH!  Their vegetarian dishes are all vegan, which is awesome.  We had the collard greens, mushrooms, and the chicken stew.  It was all SO yummy and I can't wait to go back.  The neighborhood is dodgy, but makes for interesting dining entertainment.
author: Catherine J.

description:
Moya had their soft opening tonight; grand opening is scheduled for next Monday.  I've been waiting for them to open for a while, as I live nearby.  I've been a fan of Ethiopian for a long time and was hoping they'd be at least a solid neighborhood option.

Tonight was my first visit and I'll be going back - and not just because it is convenient.  We had two dishes - the Ye Doro Wot (#25) - which is a chicken dish consisting of two drumsticks braised in a rich, dark sauce and the Kifto (#18), a fairly standard Ethiopian classic you can find most places.

Both were good and at different ends of the spice spectrum.  The ye do wot was our favorite of the two.  The meat was falling off the bone (in the best possible way) and came with a mild, gravy-like sauce and a hard-boiled egg. It reminded us of a mole - with complex, deep rich flavors.

We ordered the classic kifto the way they like to serve it - rare.  It was fairly spicy, but adding a little ayb (the cottage cheese served on the side) cut the spice nicely.  This was a solid dish, but I'll try the two other versions of kifto on the menu on future visits to figure out which is my favorite.

They topped of the meal with a few of the delicious Italian cookies from the nearby Dolce Italia cookie company (wholesale only at the moment, it appears.)  These were excellent!

I really liked Moya and have hopes of it being a lasting addition to the neighborhood.  They stated they are hoping to set up a traditional Ethiopian coffee station in the near future, which should be awesome.  

Service was great - the owner's daughter waited on us and spent time telling us about the plans for the restaurant (all of which sound exciting.)  We met the owner as well - she was hard at work in the kitchen, but took time to say goodbye to us, which was nice!  

They lack a wine/beer permit at the moment, so there isn't much to cut the spiciness of the food (I'd love a beer!)  Its just starting, but it is off to a promising start in a neighborhood that has seen a plethora of great new places open.  If you're in this part of SOMA, it is worth a shot (and a great  value - entrees are about $15 each and are quite generous - well worth it!)
author: Dave H.

description:
We ate at Moya last night, and the food was solid, not spectacular. They lost a couple stars for me with their split yellow peas and collards which were both pretty bland.  Also the lamb (Ye Beg Tibs) was a little tough. I didn't mind this so much because it was my husband who ordered the lamb so it wasn't a big deal to me. The spicy red lentils, however, were excellent and the carrots and potatoes were tasty, too. 

All around it was okay, but I guess I'm spoiled by Little Ethiopia in LA. 

FYI you can't walk 20 yards in Oakland or Berkeley without passing an  Ethiopian restaurant. If Moya were in the East Bay it would have a hard time competing.
author: Emille L.

description: Moya is easily the best Ethiopian restaurant in the city, possibly the best in the whole bay area. The shuro is the best I've ever had, and if you ask for it, they will serve you injera made with 100% teff, which is what is used in Ethiopia. Besides being much healthier than regular injera, the teff injera tastes a lot better, too.
author: Tynan S.

description: Go for the veggie sampler.  My boyfriend loves this ethnic urban adventure of flavor.  For me it is a little heavy, but its good for what it is!
author: Rebecca F.

description: Clean place, friendly service, super tasty food. I stuck to vegie offerings and was thrilled to eat such delicious Ethiopian food. I only wish I had had time to go back for seconds.
author: Debbie S.

description:
Wow. This was excellent Ethiopian food that took me back to Ethiopia. I was there for 3 weeks in 2008 and fell in love with the fantastic food (easily 10x better than anything else in Sub-Saharan Africa, where I spent 6 months). I found the food here at Moya was pretty authentic. 
The restaurant is charming and the food varied and delicious. The place was nearly empty at lunch time so I guess it is new. Get in there now before it gets hugely popular!

If you have not tried Ethiopian it is fun to eat the delicious dishes with your hands, using injeera bread scraps to pick up the food. They will give you utensils if you ask but that is half the fun. They also keep the amazing injeera coming as much as you need and the staff are attentive. 

The pleasant waitress (owner?) warned us that the Kittfo and Ye Doro Wat were quite spicy (not always good at lunch) so we tried the Vegi Combo and Ye Bere Tibs (Beef in mildly spicy bere bere sauce) which were very good. In retrospect though I bet this was kind of an American palette "gringo spicy" so I am game to go back and try those since they were among my favorite dishes in Ethiopia. 

I liked this place even better than the other two Ethiopian places I have tried in SF (Assab on Geary and a different place on Irving). I will go back.
author: Mike L.

description:
This place was the best Ethiopian restaurant I've ever been to, and I've been to a lot of them. First off, gluten-free injera. NO where else has this. As a person who is sensitive to gluten, this is really great since I can actually enjoy Ethiopian food again. It's been so long! The food is great. We ordered a vegetarian combo, buzena tibs, and ye beg tibs. All were excellent, fresh, and perfectly salted and not overly spiced. Just a perfect balance of flavors. They also served a good variety of beverages including Numi Organic Teas. 

Service was excellent and attentive and the staff were all very nice and kind. The bathrooms were clean. We'll definitely be back!
author: Stewart L.

description:
I'm so happy there's an Ethiopian restaurant in SOMA!!!

What we had:

Azifa- Delicious cold appetizer of lentils, tomatoes, onions & spices served with Ethiopian flatbread;
Moya Special Kitfo- Mouth-watering kitfo ( I love kitfo!!) mixed with collard greens, Ethiopian home made cottage cheese, and wonderfully spicy!
Atkilti Wot- Seasonal vegetables simmered in spices.

Everything was fresh and delicious served family style on a huge plate. The service was attentive and we also got to meet the owner, who is fabulous. In fact, all her staff is top notch! The decor is also elegant; Moya is a real gem in the neighborhood.  

We were happily stuffed and can't wait to try everything else on the menu, including coffee!
author: Akasha A.

description:
Came here after dinner for some coffee. Didn't realize it was a full on Ethiopian spot. Yelp had this under "Coffee & Tea" in their app. Yummy lattes (no flavored). Service was nice and friendly. Had us try some of the injera bread other reviewers have raved about.

Bookmarked for a future visit!
author: Carolyn J.

description:
I never had Ethiopian Food before, but I would go back in a heartbeat.
Moya is a lovely little Restaurant with a good atmosphere and very friendly service.
My friend and I were skipping through the menu whilst waiting on our other friends and I mentioned I did not know what to expect. The waitress overheard us, came over and started explaining Ethopian Food. she also recommended 2 of the dishes - one meat and one veggie.
She sounded very convincing so we decided to order the recommended Shuro and the Ye Doro Wot. We also ordered Kifto and Misir Wot.

All dishes were served with salad on a huge pice of Ethiopian bread. It smelled delicious (spicy and rich in flavors, texture similar to Indian food, but slightly less layers of spiciness/richness) and looked wonderful. Once the bread was brought we started digging in.
My fav was the chicken marinated in lemon juice. I simple could not stop eating it. The meat was cooked to perfection - falling of the bone the minute you touched it.
The raw beef was delicious too, very filling though. 
My friends loved the Shuro - fairly spicy but irresistible.
We got to try three different versions of food, and I recommend the real deal - it tastes like dark bread - mhhhhh.

All in all it was a successful evening - very social - eating family style from one big plate with your fingers, great & friendly service and extremely reasonable priced.
author: Angelika R.

description: Nice small place just before market on 9th. I paid roughly about $11 for chicken stir fry. Their food was quite delicious but kinda greasy. So my stir fry came with a bowl of chicken cooked in some gravy and spices along with salad and probably yellow lentils(?) and some bread (that was really different). Used credit card and the service was fast. Not sure if I'll go again but all in all a nice meal.
author: G B.

description: Awesome food with awesome service to go with it! Many people think only the meat-eaters have fun at Ethiopian restaurants like this one, but as an almost- vegetarian myself, I can say whole-heartedly that you will not regret eating here If you are a vegetarian!! The veggie combo gives you a good amount of each of the typical Ethiopian vegetable dishes which I believe are the most delicious of this culture's food. For those of you who are into meat, though, the doro wot is phenomenal, as is the kitfo (its raw meat but just keep an open mind!). As an Ethiopian myself I have often been disappointed with the food at Ethiopian restaurants because they are never authentic, but this restaurant is the REAL DEAL!! Give it a try and you will be thankful :)
author: Mo M.

description:
I really liked this place.

The food is damn good. Probably the best Ethiopian food I've had. Certainly the best I've had in SF.

Also, the people are super, duper nice. 

The space itself is not sceney; and they don't serve alcohol. But taking it for what it is, it's a great spot. We'll definitely be back.
author: jon c.

description:
It's been ages since I had Ethiopian food--probably 15+ years ago.  Clearly, it's been too long.

Clean, cozy, and yummy smells are a winning trifecta in my book!  The food was delicious...I shared the veggie combo and it was PLENTY of food.  Tasty injera too, and a gluten free option is available.

Also loved the friendly service and strong coffee.  A definite winner!
author: Ann V.

description:
I am so pleased to see FolSoMa proliferating east of 7th Street (Folsom Street's little corridor of great restaurants is adapting FolSoMa nomenclature, if you're scratching your head at that word).

I have been excited to eat at Moya since I first had a taste a month or so ago at an Urban Solutions community get together co-hosted by Moya and Fondue Cowboy on the other side of Russ Street.

A mother and two daughters, who are incredibly warm and welcoming I might add,  have been pouring their souls for nearly a year into getting this space fixed up and opening for business .... you know you want to cheer for their success!!  I am cheering for their success, and will be telling friends to give Ethiopian food a try.

This is a fun place to eat - you get to eat using an Ethiopian bread to scoop up the veggies/meats of your entree.  It took me a few torn pieces to get the hang of it, but I was soon sopping up and scooping my entree with the best of them.

I tried a lamb dish. The funny thing is that the meat wasn't all that hot - and even mentions in the menu that the meats aren't necessarily well done.  It was very tasty, spiced up with some great natural flavors.

I think the real triumph at Moya is the selection of vegetarian dishes. I tried the mushroom dish this go around.  It was served hot, and it was simply excellent!  I need to try a few more, but my gut tells me that you cannot go wrong with the Vegetarian entrees at Moya.

I wish the ladies of Moya nothing but the best of success with their new restaurant.  My boyfriend and I will certainly be back for lunch and/or dinner to further explore the menu and help support this new addition to our neighboring FolSoMa restaurant corridor.
author: Jamie W.

description:
This is the cuuuuutest place.  

A couple of friends and I were going back and forth about where to eat.  We've been to most of the places in the neighborhood and we just decided to start walking.  Luckily, we passed by this restaurant and saw it had opened!  

We were greeted by a very friendly group of people working there.  It turns out (after talking with the owner and her daughter), it's owned by a single mother who clearly kicks butt and takes names.  

We ordered a chicken dish (Ye Doro Tibs) and the vegetarian sampler.  It was all really, really delicious and different.  The price was great, too!  3 of us ate for less than $40.  After the meal - I asked if they had anything not posted on the menu that was on the dessert tip.  She brought us a few pieces of this breakfast-y flatbread-y stuff with honey  (sorry I don't remember the name of the dish).  It wasn't on the menu, so I don't know that they would offer it to everyone.  Regardless, I was super impressed with her willingness to go out of her way to find us something sweet.

All in all - AWESOME experience.  I hope this place does well.  Will definitely be back very soon.
author: MacKenzie P.

description: Delicious. Ordered a spicy chicken dish with injera bread and salad. Hit the spot.
author: Kevin A.

description:
I walk by this place everyday on my way to work and they always have the windows open while they cook/prep for the day. The smell is amazing and the yummy food lives up to it. This place is great for people that have never tried Ethiopian cuisine and didn't know of a good place to start.

One other thing, they make a really good cup of Ethiopian coffee.
author: Davin A.

description:
a few friends and I where in the city just hanging out and we happened to be parked in-front of Moya's while talking about a place to go get a bite to eat before heading home to watch the ball game.
so looking up from our location we said this makes the best sense none of us had ever eaten this kind of food before, and considering we like to think of our selves as foodies we said why not lets give it a shot.
and boy where we ever surprised on the flavors in the food and also how nice the people in the restaurant where that worked there it was a family owned place, so we ordered our food and had a seat it took about 30 min to get our food well worth the time for such great food.
I would say go try this place and be blown away.
they serve things on bread as plates kinda and the BREAD is so so so GOOD.
I might make a trip into the city next time just to go eat at this place again.
author: vache a.

description: My favorite Ethiopian place in San Francisco. I've only had the doro tibs here, but a number of friends have sampled the entire menu and they've all had great experiences. The food is spicy, flavorful and the ladies behind the counter are the nicest gals around!
author: Aakash D.

description:
Was looking forward to trying this place as we always are on the hunt for another Ethiopian/Eritrean spot

Very pleasant staff and service is fine...Not crazy about some of the interior appointments that they decided on...It's a cash only business so there's a little ATM right alongside one of the dining tables for quick cash...Just a bit odd to be punching along the ATM while sitting over someone else's dinner - might be a good idea to move that money maker somewhere else

But, ahh, then there's the handicap/automatic front door that power assists opening/closing of the door with a solid 3-5 second pause with it wide open...Now in some places this wouldn't be a terrible thing necessarily but in an establishment where the layout of the resto is long & narrow like Moya it merely acts as a funnel for wind/cold...Terrible idea...We kept moving further and further back from the front to avoid the elements

As for the most important aspect, the food, it was a mixed bag...The tasty salad for an appetizer left us hopeful & excited that the entrees would be equally tasty but were left a bit underwhelmed...Some of the veggie dishes had good flavor & seasoning but the meat dishes fell pretty flat...In particular, the beef was overcooked & tough...A bit disappointing, to be honest.

Assab still seems the one to beat, for us
author: Barca F.

description: My friend, Sarah, recommended this place as a place to eat before attending a lecture at CIIS.  I realized when I walked in that I hadn't had Ethiopian food since I left Fort Collins.  Now that I have found this place, I will be having Ethiopian food much more frequently.  I will go out of my way to eat here and I'm noting that it is close to Slim's and will be a good pre-show place to meet up for food.  If they only served alcohol, this place would be perfect.  The veggie sampler was amazing.  Everything we ate was amazing.  The restaurant itself is small and not particularly special, but the food.... RECOMMEND!!!  Also, who doesn't like to eat with their hands
author: Jenn M.

description:
Everything about my experience at Moya was great.  This was the first Ethiopian I have had in the Bay area, but it is better than my other experiences, even when I was living in the DC area.  

The staff was very personable and spent time explaining how to eat Ethiopian as well as suggesting dishes to the people in my party who had not had Ethiopian before.  Our sever even explained some of the cultural significance of different dishes.  

The flavors were rich and not overpowered by heat.  The sauces had a great mixture of savory and spicy, and were not overly greasy.  The injera was fresh and of perfect consistency.  We started with the ye timatim fit fit, which was a fresh and lite salad, perfect for introducing those new to Ethiopian food to the injera.  The vegetarian combination was very good.  The gomen, collard greens, was a stand-out as far as the vegetarian dishes.  The Moya Special Kitfo was full of a great herbal flavor that I couldn't quite figure out.  The ye doro wot was also delicious, and even better when mixed with a little of the ayb (home made cottage cheese) as suggested by our server.

The interior is new and clean, with ample seating available when we arrived for an early dinner at 6:30pm.  The surrounding area is not very residential, so there was ample parking on the same block when we arrived.

I am definitely excited to go back and sample more of their menu.  By interacting with the servers, cooks and owner, you can tell that they work hard to make delicious "home-style" Ethiopian food and very proud of the product.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Quick proxie review for my father; the Terror of the SOMA Dining Circuit.

When you order something and say "No Lamb?"  We expect "No Lamb."

Clean, friendly, true to its roots.  But the Terror is disappointed with being tricked into eating lamb.  =(
author: William C.

description:
This place was amazing; clean, welcoming and run and owned by two women.  I loved that it was a family run place.  For two of us, getting the teff injera (which is actually what injera is supposed to be made with; many places cut the teff with flour; teff is also gluten free!) and the all veggie platter, it was a grand total of $23. 

We didn't even finish it all and we were stuffed......

The food was colorful, flavorful and just amazing....can't wait to hit it up again!
author: Nicki F.

description: I'm a city girl so I love the idea of Ethiopian food on the fly in a pay first sit down DIY hip atmosphere. I ordered the mushroom chicken dish and my sister had the gorbonzo beans. We loved everything and will be back soon!
author: Beaky L.

description: Excellent food.  Very fresh and the spices are fantastic.  Service is great, location is convenient to Twitter, Dolby, and Fox Plaza.  Very short walk.
author: April M.

description:
Ethiopian restaurants are popular for their veggie fare and in this regard Moya did not disappoint. Their menu boasts plenty of veggie options, the staples of any good Ethiopian place -- a veggie combo and shuro, and even a tofu dish! I ordered the veggie combo (vegan) with my date, and we both left full. I look forward to coming back again and trying the shuro and appetizers!

Service was super friendly, food tasty (misir wot was my favorite) and  prices very reasonable! Good injera and being open for lunch earns them bonus points. A few new-restaurant kinks but I have no doubt they will be worked out. 

Having an Ethiopian place downtown is going to be very satisfying for my taste buds but very dangerous for my pocketbook. :)
author: Dana S.

description:
I'm not an expert in Ethiopian cuisine, but this place is pretty good. The place is clean and well decorated. Everyone is greeted with a smile. The server was attentive. 
The best thing was the split yellow peas (Kik Alitcha). It was soft, mushy, and had the right amount of tumeric. 
The bere tibs were good, but just a bit dry and bland. I wonder if it was my fault, since I told the waitress that I didn't want to be hit over the head with spice. (I'm glad she asked though!)
The injera was awesome...like a perfect pancake, used to grab all of the goodness on the plate.
All in all...I would give the food 3 and a half stars, but the service bumps it up to 4.
Oh yeah...the waitress DID ask if it was ok to dump the meat dish on the big plate of vegetables. If I was a vegetarian, I would've REALLY appreciated it! But i'm not... so DUMP AWAY!
author: Siao W.

description:
