Nice staff, but kind of tastes like a watered down or Americanized version of Ethiopian food. Definitely less spices and not as spicy. The dish we ordered also came with salad with something like an Italian dressing - kind of weird. 

Not the best atmosphere for dinner (I'm sure at lunch it's buzzing with all the people working in that area) but for dinner service, you'll mostly just run into the crazies on the street. It's also more like an Ethiopian cafe versus restaurant.
author: Maria Y.

description: I'm not a natural Ethiopian food lover, but I had a dish donated from them at a fundraiser & it was awesome. I kept walking by & smelling the amazing aroma of spices & I had to go.  I'm hooked.
author: Ima S.

description:
Good Ethiopian food is hard to find in San Francisco. With that said, I welcome this new addition to my neighborhood!

First off, the staff was very friendly and attentive. The restaurant was very clean and inviting, nothing fancy, but you can tell that the owners put some good thought into their investment.

I ordered #21, yere bere tibs and Eric ordered the #15, vegetarian combo per the suggestion of our server. The vegetarian combination plate was tasty, aromatic and very fresh - enough for two people. The yere bere tibs (beef) was tender, juicy, and flavourful. Both were served with ample amounts of fresh injera (flat bread).  The servings are generous, I'm sure that we could have shared them with two more people. We left the restaurant very satisfied and stuffed to the gills.

Overall, I enjoyed everything on my first visit and I will definitely come back with reinforcements!

Welcome to the neighborhood Moya!!
author: Sam H.

description:
Great food, boring but clean atmosphere, good service. Eating with hands is always fun.

Moya is the new kid on the block, and doing pretty well. Their food is solid and just as good as Ethiopian anywhere. It lacks a little bit in unique atmosphere. Most locally owned ethnic restaurants try to play to their unique flavor and culture of origin, but this one tries to have a clean feel instead of an ethnic feel. It's an interesting choice that might make it more business suit oriented, but makes it a lot less of a fun experience than a place with the short tables and different feel of a place that takes you out of the American mindset for your meal.

The service was great, we got a table right on arrival and drinks served immediately. Food service took 11 minutes for salads and another 5 for dinner. the salads were interesting, served on the flatbread, but consisting of chopped and dressed romaine, there was no good way to eat the salads and they didn't really go with the flatbread for eating the rest of the meal. the food and flatbread were good, and the price was reasonable.

Will I return, possibly, but I'll go for the food alone, not for the experience of something very different.
author: Matthew R.

description: i mean delicious, really spicy and well prepared entrees.. i had the beef dor wat and it was homey and comforting. This place has heart
author: alex m.

description:
For some odd reason while it seems as if you can find really good Ethiopian food on every corner of Oakland and Berkeley, there has always been a shortage of really good places in San Francisco. That shortage continues even with this new addition.

Moya is a decent but not great Ethiopian food. It will get much love from the gluten-free folks for having gluten-free injera and it will get love from the hardcore carnivores for having three different kinds of kitfo, a sirloin beef dish usually served rare. 

The portion are decent but the prices are 5 dollars more than at most Ethiopian places in the bay area for the same quality of food. 

I'll may go back but for really good Ethiopian, I'll still head to a couple of places in the East Bay.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Folsom Street has several new culinary delights, one of which, Moya, caught my attention as it was near my gym. Incredibly friendly service, my friend Treven and I had the vegetarian dish as well as the chicken dish, which was expertly poured onto the plate while being served. You eat with your hands, so diners ensure to wash them before digging in!

Spicy, exotic, and very filling, I liked to food and the service. $15 for the chicken dish was a bit high, as it only came with a few pieces of chicken smothered in an amazing sauce. Overall, I think this place is well worth the visit. Be sure to say hello to mom in the back, who is one of the chefs!
author: David G.

description:
Moya has awesome Shiro (shuro), although it's a bit expensive. The menu says $12 but it was actually $15. It's so good though so definitely worth it. The mixed vegetable combo is a good deal, and they give you a decent amount of injera. I LOVE Ethiopian food and have eaten my fair share in East Africa so I'm a bit of a snob about it, but this place is definitely worth checking out.

They're cash only so come prepared for that.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Having tried Ethiopian only once before at an Afro Fest in Toronto Canada, I had been keen to give it a real whirl again. Especially since 100% teft anjara (the crepes all the food is served on) is 100% GLUTEN FREE!! woohoo! (its an extra $2 for the 100% teft anjara, BUT even my gluten-full friends agreed the taste is amazing!@)

Speaking of amazing, the food was really great! With 2 other friends, we split the veggie combo ($15), plus got 1 other veggie side ($6), so amazing meal for 3 = $24 + tax & tip. Unheard of for SF! 

PLUS all the food was made to order, and the spice combos are made by the owner's mother/server's grandmother. Its owned by a wonderful woman whose also the cook, and her 2 amazing daughters help to run the place too. Supporting female entrepreneurs feels awesome too :)

This SOMA treasure is a great find for a cheap, filling, delicious and unique meal experience to share with friends. Also, I found eating with your hands provides such a closer experience with you food too.
Enjoy!
author: Vanessa C.

description: Well spiced with excellent injera and generous portions. My new favorite ethiopian spot. They do a good job packing up takeout. The kitfo, tibs, and veggies were all fantastic.
author: Andy G.

description: A group of us came by here for dinner and were really pleased with our experience. The service was really fast compared to other Ethiopian restaurants we've eaten at in the Bay Area, and it was nice to be able to specify how spicy we wanted our food. We really enjoyed the mushroom tibs and the shuro. The misir wot was more al dente than others we've tried, but the flavor was still spot on. Also the injera was thinner and doughier than I'm used to, but again, it was still delicious. I will definitely come back here again when I'm in the area!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I live around the corner from this place and have been wanting to try it for so long as its spicy aromas waft throughout the neighborhood. I finally got to last night and was not let down at all.

My friend and I split the veggie sampler. The red lentil stew was my favorite. The house salad had a delightfully tangy dressing. There was plenty of injera and we finished it off with a baklava-style desert I didnt catch the name of. We were both sufficiently stuffed.

The service was fast the the cashier/waitress was friendly. I learned they do take-out so I will definitely be taking advantage of that!
author: Sonia S.

description: I happened upon this place and I highly recommend me. The food is good and staff is friendly. Go with the veggie sampler and you can't go wrong.
author: Alex G.

description:
The food is great, and the customer service is better.

I went there at the end of the lunch rush, and truth be told, they were out of a few things I wanted to order.

However, they were really helpful in steering me toward alternatives, and when they found out they were out of a second thing me and my companion wanted to order, they comped a full half of the meal, which was awesome.

I also loved that this place was totally woman operated!

With the great customer service and the fact that this is one of the only Ethiopian restaurants I could find open before 4p, I definitely see myself returning!
author: Becca B.

description:
I had never tried Ethiopian Food. Our server was pleasant, friendly and very helpful. 

We ordered the Chicken and Mixed Vegetables. It was more then enough for the 2 of us. They brought out more Injera. The spices used reminded me of Indian food, but simpler... really enjoyed it . I work in the neighborhood and would love for this restaurant to be a success.
author: nisha c.

description:
WOW

Beautiful decor.
Friendly gracious service.
Gluten-free teff.
Freshly cooked meat and vegetables right before our eyes??

I didn't think it was possible before to get Ethiopian with all of these positives.

Moya is now my favorite Ethiopian restaurant anywhere, and I've eaten at quite a few.  

Definitely a gem!
author: Beth C.

description: Food was so tasty. Had the veggie combo and the beef tips. Delicious! Cool mural on the wall too.
author: Heidi G.

description: Paid over $40 for 2 small portions (self serve ) and food was mediocre. Far way overpriced for the quality of the service and food..
author: ferhat n.

description:
My girlfriend and I recently moved into the neighborhood and decided to check this place out last night with another friend.  We ordered an Azifa for an appetizer and Kitfo, Ye Doro Tibs, and Ye Beg Wot.  All three of the main dishes were great.  The chicken (Ye Doro Tibs) was probably my favorite of the three, which is saying a lot because I'm normally not big on chicken dishes.  Everything had a great amount of spice and was wholly filling.  For $20 a person we were beyond stuffed when we left the restaurant.  

The staff was very friendly and would constantly bring us more injera as we devoured the ones in front of us.  The only negative surprise was that they didnt serve beer or wine, but that's something that I should have looked up before we went.  Overall we had a great experience and will definitely be coming back.
author: Yuri Y.

description: Came here for dinner and tried the Kitfo, an ethiopian steak tartare medium rare. It was really delicious, and a good sized portion. The owners are nice and the place is very simple and clean.
author: Darnell L.

description: Don't do it!! Zero stars!! Worst food I have every eaten, the lettuce leaf was the only decent thing on the plate. So much garlic I have to go hide away from the public now. My wife just started laughing because there was nothing on the plate she could eat and I'd chosen the restaurant. She will not let this one down
author: Simon K.

description:
We're regulars here, and we love it.

We've been Ethiopian food fanatics for more than 3 years, and we eat at Ethiopian restaurants more frequently than we do any other type of restaurant. We've been to at least 6 different restaurants in the south bay and San Francisco, and Moya is hands down the best Ethiopian place in SF. Our other favorite places are Zeni and Rehoboth (both in San Jose). 

The other Ethiopian places in San Francisco are a little off. Sheba Piano Lounge has decent flavors, but it's loud, the portions are small, and it doesn't feel authentic. Assab Eritrean is a good introduction to Ethiopian food, but the food lacks the depth of flavors and spices.

Moya is great. We usually get the kitfo (ground beef) raw, extra spicy, and it never disappoints. The veggie combo is also very good, and it seems to be improving every time we go. I'm guessing as they've become more popular, the veggie dishes (especially the bean-based ones) are fresher and less dry. 

Everything else we've tried is also very good -- ye beg tibs (lamb stew), shuro (finely-pureed chickpea), ye timatim selata (shreded bread in dressing), ye beg wot (another lamb stew) -- although I wish the ye timatim selata were a little more lemon-y.

Hope more people find this place, but not too many more people; I don't want to wait for a table.
author: Peter D.

description: Perfect spot for lunch..... It would be great if they have meat combination combo like they do in vegetarian
author: Nim V.

description: Not even in a pinch. I love Ethiopian food and gave this place a second chance. Greens had way too much butter or oil, both split peas were bland paste with a hint of heat. Too salty as well; I had to gulp down water for hours afterward. Worse, this food left me gaseous as Cassius, and that is pretty hard to do someone who has been a vegetarian for over 25 years.
author: Robert T.

description:
Great Ethiopian restaurant owned/operated by a nice woman and her daughters.  It's so nice to support small local businesses, but Moya makes it easy with their awesome food.  I had the MIsir Wot, which they kindly put on a separate plate so that my veggie dish wouldn't be "contaminated" with everyone else's meat.  Thankfully I shared because everyone else loved my dish.  It was so good and the injera was delicious.  

Wish I could stop by for their lunch special, but it's too far away.  Sad :(  But honestly their normal prices aren't expensive and it's totally worth the price.  They also seem to have an $8 corkage fee?  So that's super cheap too.
author: Olivia T.

description: As someone who came from Washington, DC where the Ethiopian restaurants and population are plentiful, this place was a disappointment. It was super expensive, the food was bland, even the injera bread was bland. I can't believe so many people enjoy this place, they must not have had authentic Ethiopian food before. I will not be returning to this restaurant.
author: Felecia M.

description: For a school project, we each had to present on a culture including holidays, customs, foods, etc. One of my classmates did a presentation on the culture of Ethiopia and ever since, I've been wanting to try ethiopian food. Fast forward 1 year, I finally got around to it! For her presentation, she actually brought in some injera for us to try but it was too sour for my liking. However, she did say that it tastes a lot better dipped in sauces. Well, she was right! My friend and I got the vegetarian platter and also the chicken drumsticks. The injera tasted so much better eaten with the vegetables and chicken. Out of the vegetables, my favorite would have to be the yellow pea stew. The chicken was really tender and basically fell off the bone. The chicken came with more sauce to dip the injera in whereas the vegetables were dryer. Overall, a great first experience and I can't wait to try more of their other dishes!
author: Monica W.

description: I was excited about Moya because I am a huge Ethiopian fan and my home town had a legendary family owned spot. However, this night I think was not an ideal night to go. The server did NOT seem interested in her job this evening. I was told no more than once and she also got our order wrong. Unfortunately, the food was not good enough to make up for this. Still looking for a great Ethiopian place!
author: Robert M.

description: I totally give it 5 stars. The place opened on Saturday and I have been there twice already. Great service, good price and a nice clean simple place.I hope they will get a beer and wine license. The food is very authentic trust me I am Ethiopian.
author: Teddy d.

description: Moya is so delicious. Got the veggie platter and the rare beef dish that is their signature.  I didn't eat any of the beef, but my BF said it was delicious.  Service was better than last time and no more floaties in the water.  The two dishes were more than enough for 2 people, and I even had left over veggies and injera to bring home.  About $30 before tax and tip.  Not too bad.  I wish there was an 1/2 order sized veggie platter for one person.
author: Skye W.

description: This is the only Ethiopian place in the city that consistently has gluten-free injera! The red lentils or marinated beef are our favorites, but you pretty much can't go wrong. Minus a star for being pricey - can run two people $50.
author: Raina M.

description: I love Moya. Can't stop going to this place. We always order the $15 lunch vegetarian special. So good and great value for money. Just $7.50 per person. I also recommend the lamb dish.
author: Esme V.

description:
the kitfo was GREAT and there was a HUGE portion.  the two of us stuffed ourselves to capacity and still could only finish half of it.  we also shared a veggie combo platter that was awesome.

im also a big fan of leftovers.  we had enough kitfo for leftovers and made delicious enchiladas with said leftovers.

kitfo + veggie sampler - scoutmob discount=$15
author: Christy C.

description: The best and most authentic Ethiopian food in the city, confirmed by my friend who has spend long periods of time living in Ethiopia. The family who runs the business is extremely friendly and warm.
author: Caroline Y.

description: Good ethiopian food, but not as good as some others. has gluten free teff so I am a fan!
author: BC M.

description:
I must preface my review by stating that I am pretty new to Ethiopian food (been to about 3-4 restaurants).

Having said that, I was not too impressed by the place. A big plus... it appeared clean, the lady serving was pleasant, but service was lacking and food very average (I had ordered a lamb dish) and overpriced (in terms of value for money).
author: T S.

description: Out of the three ethopian restaurants in SF i've tried, this one is my favorite so far.    The styrofoam textured cheese is really weird and not at all appetizing, but other than that everything i've had has been great and flavorful.
author: LT B.

description: Totally nontraditional Ethiopian place. Felt like a hipster cafe, with a touch of tribal decor. Very attentive staff, and the food came out quite fast. We ordered a bunch of meats and veggies, and also had the raw beef dish. All was really fresh tasting, especially the lamb. It was the first time I've had the raw beef, and that was addictive! The injera was perfectly made. Sadly, they don't have a liquor license yet, so they didn't have honey wine. The food was really good, though!
author: Joy C.

description: Great Ethiopian place.  We had lunch and did a shared plate.  The vegetarian split red lentil MISIR WOT was amazing.  The lamb (which I did not eat) was enjoyed and flavorful.  The injera was great.  The staff was friendly.  They seem to be getting steady business for dinner.  I think it is a perfect spot for lunch.  This is sure to become a neighborhood favorite for us.
author: Jessica M.

description: Dined here last night with friends (one of whom lived in Ethiopia for a few years) and we found the food to be delicious, the service friendly, and the ambiance relaxing. If you're a fan of Ethiopian food or simply looking for something different, this is a great little restaurant. The resto doesn't serve beer/wine but they are working on their "BYOB" license and it should be in place in a few months.
author: Edward R.

description: This place is spectacular. We got a lamb dish, a chicken dish, and some lentils. Everything was amazing. The owner cooks the food herself. I will be coming back quite often I'm sure.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
Friendly service, nice restaurant, well priced.
Food was very bland and uninspired. Of the 5 dishes we tried, only one was even remotely interesting. There's a lot of food but you are still left wanting something better after you finish your meal. We won't go there again.
author: Kathi E.

description: Excellent service!  The lady was super nice.  Our dishes were delicious, especially the chicken.  The flavor was very good, but  a bit too spicy and too much black pepper for me.  I'll ask them to make it milder next time.  Will definitely be back again!
author: Elena L.

description: Food quality is very good. Few selection but cool. The service is good too. Just ambians is low.
author: Ali E.

description:
i love ethiopian.  it is my favorite type of cuisine.  and moya serves some of the best ethiopian food i've tried in this country.

of course i had the vegetarian combo, and also the tofu tibs (you can get a side order portion of any of the vegetarian dishes) and they were both excellent.  the veggie combo had all the usual suspects but they were fresh and perfectly spiced.  tofu tibs is a novelty and one that i can't imagine not ordering on every visit.

but the absolute star of the restaurant is the shuro:  finely ground chickpeas spiced with 12 different spices and cooked in a covered clay pot.  i know this because our server was the chef's daughter and explained it to us.  and when we were halfway through frantically shoveling it down our throats, her mother, the owner/chef, came out and personally made sure we were in love with it.  we told her we were.

the place is small but cute and clean and the service was delightful!  i've never said delightful before but i can't think of anything else that describes the experience better.  it's pretty cool that you can get all-teff injera too!
author: kate s.

description: Easily the best ethiopean food i've had in San Francisco.  The yellow and red lentil dishes were very very good, and the collard green dish was tasty.  Each dish comes with a salad that has a very nice dressing on it.  Amanda generally gets the raw kitfo wherever she goes, and apparently they have a very good one here.  Friendly staff, easy to find parking, and the $8 lunch combo is a great deal.  Will definitely be coming back.
author: Phil J.

description: Excellent ethiopian food, and very convenient for takeout.  The owner packs the food perfectly.  Food quality is top-notch.
author: eshwar k.

description: my boyfriend and i are HUGE fans of addis in oakland and make it a point to grab ethiopian food before seeing a show at the fox. sigur ros was playing at bill graham on wednesday, so we were happy to have such delicious ethiopian food within walking distance. the food seems somewhat healthier than other ethiopian places i've tried but without a loss of flavor. i had the shuro and my boyfriend refuses to order anything but the raw kitfo. we will gladly be back!
author: ashley d.

description: Again, wonderful! Had the shuro this time, and it was totally worth the wait. I love this place! :)
author: Amanda S.

description: People are friendly, food is good, and the prices aren't that expensive. Me and my co-worker go here for lunch some times and always go away happy. Can't go wrong with this place, except the "spicy" good be more spicy!
author: Frank G.

description:
Pretty bad. 

Small portions - not a problem though because the food is so heavy and bland you won't want to eat much. Probably the worst Ethiopian I've had. Generally I end up eating too much when I go out for Ethiopian, but at this place nobody really touched the slimy and lukewarm gommen (collared greens), the kik alicha (yellow lentil stew) was dry and mealy, probably from sitting on the stove since the previous day, (we were there on the early side). The ata kilt (cabbage, potato, carrot dish) had poorly washed and sandy vegetables in it, used baby carrots, and did not taste fresh. Messer wot (red lentils) was incredibly bland, with undercooked lentils, and had no discernible spice to it. Also, maybe I'm mistaken, but it seemed like they didn't use any nitir kibe (spiced clarified butter) in the veggie dishes. The injera (which they charge extra for if you want it served like a normal Ethiopian meal) was stale. Great that it's made out of 100% teff, shame it isn't any good. The lentil salad was just awful. Undercooked dry lentils, hardly any flavor, served on stale sliced bread.

Service is barely existent, you order at the counter, get your own water and napkins. I don't mind this approach, but when a veggie combo that was clearly cooked way earlier in the day and slopped out onto a plate is $17, the place is in a shitty neighborhood, and the decor looks like your average nobody-cares-independent-coffeeshop, it's outrageous.

Oh, and no honey wine or Ethiopian beers, although I would assume they're working on that.

If you rated this place well you really should check out Enssaro, Cafe Eritrea de Afrique, or any of the other well reviewed Ethiopian/Eritrean spots in Oakland. Unless this was the off-est of off-nights, you won't want to eat at Moya anymore.
author: YUP K.

description:
Pretty good food, cheap, reasonably close to the Fidi, and open for lunch!  It's surprisingly hard to find Ethiopian food near the Fidi, and even harder to find places that aren't dinner-only.  They offer a lunch special for about $9 (can't remember the exact price, maybe $8.45, but don't quote me on that) where you pick 3 of the 4 items in the vegetarian combo.  It's not on the menu, but just ask them about the special.  3 of us shared that and the first of the two lamb dishes on the menu, (although I didn't have any of that since I'm a vegetarian, but they said it was good) and we were full and still had a tiny bit left over.  Everything tasted great!

The negatives:  almost every place has it's down-side, and here it is.  The injera was kind of cold (I saw the chef making it, so I know it's home-made, but she was making it in very large quantities, and they just grabbed our pieces off of a huge stack), and they don't have honey wine.

Otherwise, great in every other way!
author: Rachael S.

description: we got parking RIGHT IN FRONT! Wow already! Went in, only one table occupies, so we had our choice. Got menus and water quickly, pleasant server. Ordered coffees all around and our meals fairly quickly. Waited until 2 reminders to get coffee, another 5 minutes for cream (which turned the watery brew to NOT MUCH). The food served family style, so we requested separate plates to divide since all were not beef-eaters. The dishes were all tasty and the injera, served in 1/3  rollups, kept coming. We ate all the food. First time we weren't served enough to satiate our collective appetites! Friendly but inept service, portions not generous at the prices. Would not eat here again.
author: weedy t.

description: I love this place.  I work in the neighborhood and food options are limited and uninteresting.  Moya provides a super tasty lunch for a totally reasonable price.  The staff are very friendly and can help make suggestions.
author: Bitzz B.

description:
Just had a terrible dinner experience at Moya. 

The good: The restaurant was clean and bright -- simple but nice enough decor. We came in and were seated promptly and the service was fine.

The bad: after waiting 40 minutes for our food despite the fact that the resturant was nearly empty, we find that all of our dishes are lukewarm at best. I ordered the veggie combo, as I always do at ethopian places, and my date ordered a rare beef dish that the waitress reccomended. Too bad all of our dishes were practically cold by the time they got to our table! Even looking past that it was luke-warm, the flavor wasn't there. I can't recommend the food based on our experience. There's other good options for Ethiopian like Assab in SF, and even better options in the east bay which you can check out if you've got a craving for it.
author: Max L.

description: Amaziiiiing. Truly a great first time experience with Ethiopian food. I am officially in love and would recommend Moya to everyone. It's a wonderful place for groups to go and share a great meal. Prices aren't bad at all for how great the food is, they don't serve alcohol, so we did bring in our own bottle of wine, but the experience overall was wonderful.
author: nikki r.

description: I ate at Moya for the first time today and it was yummy! The decor is very modern, the food delicious, and the service was great. I will be back!
author: April M.

description: Food was superb.  The service was thoughtful and informational; all the food ingredients were explained.
author: Lindsay P.

description:
I went there yesterday for lunch for the first time.  Today I went back for lunch again.  I never do that(!!!)...

...but I desperately wanted to try more of the vegetarian options.  Yesterday I had the vegetable combo which allows you to try three dishes at once and my friend got the tofu tibs which I got to taste, so today I got the inguday tibs.  I definitely like the taste of the two tibs dishes best.  Today I decided not to order the lunch portion, but rather the full portion, and I ate it all!

Yesterday I got the teff-only injera and wasn't a big fan, ended up using most of my normal injera that was under my food.  Today she offered my friend a taste of the teff-only which I thought was nice.  But then she offered me a piece too saying that it turned out better than the one I had had yesterday.  I think she's right, it was fluffier, but I didn't really like knowing that I had paid for less than excellent quality yesterday.  I'd say I prefer the normal injera better because it's thinner and less tangy so you get to fully enjoy the flavors of the actual dishes you ordered.  You also end up filling up less on "carbs."  

But I like this place, the staff are very friendly, and I like that there are no lines during peak lunch hour.  Definitely give it a try!  I'm going back again soon to try the shuro - would've today but for the 30min notice required.  =)
author: Q E.

description:
I signed up for a yelp account just so I could add my 5 stars in support of Moya. Like many who have discovered this treasure, I have gluten-intolerance which makes eating out more difficult than it used to be. I was near tears when I found out about the 100%-teff injera. 

I have enjoyed each dish I've tried here. I even like the salad with the injera, but I can understand why some diners would prefer a fork for that part of the meal. 

Tonight I'm taking two friends there for the first time in celebration of their recent wedding. Everyone I have turned on to Moya has loved it. Yes, I agree, the atmosphere is not the main attraction. However, I find that the fun of eating with our hands from a colorful shared platter more than compensates for a lack of decor. 

I always end an evening of dining at Moya full and content and feeling good about how healthy and clean the food is. I hope to inspire others to support this restaurant.
author: Alicia D.

description: I love this place. Great food, quick service nice SOMA vibe. The injera is great! We usually get the veggie sampler and the chicken stir fry dish. Very feeling and makes for great left overs. This is a clean, family owned business. I LOVE Moya.
author: Ronnie M.

description:
Ok to be fair. The chicken I ordered for 12 dollars was excellent. It was just chicken, however. Not served with even a two bite salad. I went with two other friends. One ordered VEGETARIAN and one ordered BEEF. The veggie plate came on a large dish with injara. Then the waitress poured the beef dish on the big plate with the other person's order, I rescued my chicken from the same fate. A REAL STRICT VEGETARIAN WOULD HAVE CRAPPED IN THEIR PANTS BY NOW..
We ordered coffee when we came in. The waitress had to be reminded we wanted it NOW. It arrived in a small cup. After asking for the coffee three times, and then the cream repeatedly, when another worker, not our waitress, brought it to us, MY COFFEE WAS COLD. They never refilled the cup.
The service was slow and there were only two other tables occupied.
Besides the chicken being cooked well, one star, the other star is for 
CLEANLINESS..
and I would not go back..
even if someone else is paying..
author: Eugenia P.

description: The food was good (the chickpea dish had the best flavor, the lentils were just okay), but the atmosphere is seriously lacking. We went on Thursday night at 8pm, and it was empty. Nice to not have to wait, but I wouldn't go here for the ambiance, or even the feeling of a real restaurant. It feels more like a cafe that just happens to have ethiopian food.  It made me miss Massawa on Haight!
author: Mary T.

description:
Just had a fantastic dinner at Moya - the food is delicious, the prices are great, and the women that run it are extremely sweet. 

We ordered the veggie combo, the chicken tibs, and the lamb wot. All of the food was incredibly tasty! We ordered the regular ol' injera, but the ladies brought us complimentary teff injera just so we could sample it. It was yummy!

I'm thrilled to see this new addition to my neighborhood!
author: Madhu G.

description:
Went to the grand opening the other night and was very impressed.  The friendly atmosphere and warm family feeling of the restaurant is apparent as soon as you enter the door!

The buffet was great, plenty of fresh, seasoned lamb, beef, chicken and tofu.  The collared greens and lentils were my absolute favorites.

I'll be back! Good luck with the new business!
author: Jason C.

description: We stopped in for a late lunch based on a Yelp review and were not disappointed. We had the vegetarian combo and it was outstanding. Both our waitress and her mother, the owner and chef, were welcoming, pleasant and very helpful. If you are gluten- free it's good to know that they can accommodate your dietary needs with a special gluten-free version of their wrap.
author: Theresa H.

description: Awesome vegan combination with all teff injera.  More spice and flavor than many other Ethiopian restaurants.  Great prices. Friendly staff.
author: Jill B.

description: very good food, but spongy bread was cold.  service was very sweet.
author: pochini m.

description:
This is our neighborhood, and we're so glad to see businesses like this one and others opening down here.  We locals are starving for fun, eclectic and high-quality food establishments that don't require a drive or a muni-ride, and Moya delivers!

We ate there for the first time this evening, and the food was excellent.  We had the Lentils and one of the chicken entrees, along with a generous helping of the injera bread.  Great new and interesting ethnic flavors.

The only thing holding back a five-star rating is the ambiance/decor.  As an Ethiopian restaurant, I would expect a lot more African-inspired vibrant color and music.  Right now, it's a newly renovated, perfectly clean, pleasant but somewhat "beige" environment.  I don't want to judge too harshly - they're new and probably want to get into a groove before they start livening up the place.

The staff is very friendly (we met the owner's daughter), and we're happy to have this establishment in our community.  Please come check them out, enjoy a great meal with friendly service, and support this new business.
author: Sig L.

description: For a good, inexpensive Ethiopian meal, this is the place. I keep going back and the owners and servers are uniformly warm and friendly - and I love the food.  The Kitfo is not to be missed, esp. the spicy version, and they make the best injera (bread) I've had in SF - including a gluten-free version, also delicious.
author: Steve S.

description: This is, by far, the most authentic Ethiopian Restaurant in San Francisco.  I spent a bit over a year studying in Addis Abba and ate Ethiopian every day.  Eating at MOYA was like going back to the kitchen of the family in Addis Abba who served as my sponsors.  They don't have a Liquor License, so I missed the traditional Tej, but the food... was spectacular.  We ordered Kitfo (raw), Doro wat, Gomen, Shuro and, of course, Injera... the wonderful pancake like bread.  The service is properly attentive and friendly.  The place is clean, the kitchen staff are all Ethiopian, the food is spectacular... what more could you ask.  Go and see....
author: EDWARD S.

description: AMAZING MUSHROOMS. Next time I may just order like 5 orders of these and take whatever I cannot fit into my stomach home. Other items tend to be a bit sweet, but tasty and injeera is good and dark (don't like the lighter kind, it tends to fall apart). Seems family run and the people are really nice.
author: Ara S.

description: My husband, 7 yr old son and I had a five star family dining event at moya. Our son, who generally prefers not to branch out from chicken tenders, pizza or burgers,  ate everything on the vegetarian sampler platter and eating with his hands or giant pancakes was nothing but fun! Prices were reasonable, addis tea was spicy and delicious, the service was great. They also do take out! Use your right hand. We'll be back!
author: Amanda H.

description: Friendly, delicious food, ridiculously cheap, nice atmosphere... I now live two blocks from Moya and I'd be lying if I said I didn't factor that in as a plus in choosing my new place.  Check it out!
author: Geoffrey U.

description: The lamb was perfect, and the veggies were good (especially the collard greens), but the chicken we ordered (chopped up white meat) was just ok.  Maybe I'll get the dark meat drumsticks next time.  The Engera was a little drier than I'm used to, but overall the meal was very good.  I do still like Cafe Ethiopia and Enssaro a little better.
author: Kryzak K.

description: Food was good / decent but not cheap @ about $15-20 per person.  I would probably go back but for the fact they don't accept credit cards.  Like I said, its not cheap and with a group of 4-5, you can easily ring-up a $100 check.  If my corner coffee barista can take credit cards with square, then a restaurant can do the same.
author: Dan E.

description: Definitely get Spicy if ordering meat dishes. Injera is made fresh in front of your eyes you get the seat at the right angle. No alcohol and cash only at this point, but there's a scoutmob deal for 50% off up to $12 which makes good eating for 2 at a great price.
author: mc b.

description: So happy we had lunch at Moya today! The injera was tangy and fresh. In fact, "fresh" is the word I kept thinking while I was eating the tasty, perfectly spiced chicken dish and greens. Service was attentive without being overbearing. The chef-owner came out and chatted briefly with us, and told us her menu reflects Ethiopian home cooking. We can't wait to go back.
author: April K.

description: I love Ethiopian food and was really looking forward to Moya after all the great reviews.  We ordered Doro Tibs and Ye Bere Tibs to go.  The Ye Bere Tibs were tough, and both dishes lacked flavor, seasoning, and depth.  The injera was good, and the service was prompt and friendly, so 1 star for each of those... I'd order take out injera from here but the food was disappointing enough that I wouldn't give the rest another chance.
author: Leann C.

description: Salam Salam Salam Moya! MOYA IS AMAZING. Best food. Best service. If you haven't gone here yet, you're missing out!
author: Joe B.

description: am thrilled to post a great review of Moya. i had dinner there after work tonight and was very impressed with both the food and the service! i also have a great place to take vegetarian and vegan friends! everything was great, but definitely try the homemade cottage cheese!
author: robyn g.

description: This place was seriously delicious and affordable. A co-worker and I went for lunch. We got the larger sized veggie combo. First of all, the food was so flavorful. Secondly, there was so much food! Finally, the price couldn't be beat $15 for two people with leftovers. I am definately going to go back there for lunch and have recommended the place to other co-workers.
author: tracey h.

description: The best Ethiopian food I have taasted, the family ho owes and runs it is so Nice and friendly.  the food was delicious, especially liked the lentils and lamb. the decor is really done well.  Try it you will also enjoy
author: mindy g.
